questions.text: A previously healthy 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He was ambulatory at the accident scene, with stable vital signs and no major external injuries except abrasions to both upper extremities. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. Temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/74 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows ecchymosis over the upper abdomen, with tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. There is no guarding or rigidity. Rectal examination is unremarkable. A CT scan of the abdomen with intravenous contrast shows a subcapsular splenic hematoma, with no contrast extravasation and minimal blood in the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with splenic injury who are hemodynamically stable, nonoperative management is warranted and consists of observation, pain management, and serial abdominal examination (including ultrasound) and hemoglobin and hematocrit measurement to monitor any further complications that may develop.

Surgical intervention is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy and splenectomy are indicated for hemodynamically unstable patients with hilar rupture.

C) INCORRECT:

As this patient is hemodynamically stable, a nonoperative approach is suitable. Because there is a significant risk that the splenic injury may progress, leading to rupture and intraabdominal bleeding, another course of management is more appropriate than analgesia and discharge home.

D) INCORRECT:

Laparotomy and partial splenic resection are indicated in peripheral splenic rupture, which this patient could have, given the subcapsular hematoma. However, this procedure is most appropriate for hemodynamically unstable patients.
questions.hint: Tenderness of the left upper quadrant and a subcapsular splenic hematoma on CT scan following significant trauma indicate splenic injury. This patient's normal heart rate and blood pressure indicate that he is currently hemodynamically stable.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, she is semiconscious and incoherent. She has shortness of breath and is cyanotic. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 59/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration on the forehead and multiple abrasions over the thorax and abdomen. There is crepitation on palpation of the thorax on the right. Auscultation of the lung shows decreased breath sounds on the right side. A crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat is heard best over the precordium. There is dullness on percussion of the right hemithorax. The lips and tongue have a bluish discoloration. There is an open femur fracture on the left. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.31


PCO2

55 mm Hg


PO2

42 mm Hg


HCO3-

22 mEq/L


O2 saturation
76%


The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An aortic dissection can be idiopathic, associated with underlying diseases, or traumatic, following blunt chest trauma. Patients with an aortic dissection can present with an acute onset of severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back, hypertension (though hypotension is also seen when the dissection is complicated by cardiac tamponade or aortic rupture), weak or asymmetric peripheral pulses, and different blood pressures in the upper extremities. Pneumomediastinum is not a feature of aortic dissection.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade can occur following blunt chest trauma. A patient with cardiac tamponade would experience cardiogenic shock and classically present with Beck triad. This patient's symptoms are not typical of cardiac tamponade.

C) CORRECT:

Tracheobronchial injuries such as a bronchial rupture can occur after a high-speed trauma. A bronchial rupture can present with Hamman sign (as a result of the pneumomediastinum) and respiratory acidosis (due to alveolar hypoventilation from airway obstruction and atelectasis). The dullness on percussion in the right hemithorax suggests a fluid collection. In the context of recent trauma, this finding likely represents an associated hemothorax. Patients with a tracheobronchial injury may develop a pneumothorax or a pneumomediastinum which reaccumulates even after a thoracostomy.

D) INCORRECT:

Flail chest can be caused by blunt chest trauma. The flail segment, consisting of multiple adjacent ribs broken in multiple places, would be evident on physical examination. Additionally, paradoxical breathing (the flail segment moves opposite to the chest wall as the patient breaths) would be present. Although this patient may have rib fractures due to the high-speed trauma, the examination is inconsistent with a flail chest.
Image Description:

Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

E) INCORRECT:

Tension pneumothorax is often caused by high-speed trauma such as a motor vehicle collision. Patients usually exhibit hyperresonance on percussion (instead of dullness) and present with hemodynamic compromise. Because this patient is relatively hemodynamically stable, tension pneumothorax is an unlikely diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Myocardial rupture can be caused by blunt chest trauma. Patients with a myocardial rupture experience acute hemodynamic deterioration with jugular venous distention on exam, but this patient's blood pressure is stable. Because of the high mortality associated with myocardial rupture, it would also be unlikely that this patient would have survived such trauma 30 minutes later.

G) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism can be caused by embolism of fat following a femoral fracture and typically presents with nonspecific findings including pleuritic chest pain and pleural effusion. While chest pain cannot be excluded in this patient and the dullness on percussion may represent an effusion, pulmonary embolism would not manifest with the crepitus on palpation, Hamman sign, and decreased breath sounds, and is, therefore, an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with subcutaneous emphysema (crepitation on palpation), decreased breath sounds, and crunching sounds synchronous with the heartbeat (Hamman sign) following blunt chest trauma. These findings are consistent with pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain 35 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the helmeted driver of a scooter hit by a truck. On arrival, he is alert and oriented with a Glasgow Coma Scale rating of 14. His temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 33/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over his anterior abdomen and extremities. There is a 2.5-cm (1-in) laceration on the left side of the chest. There are decreased breath sounds over the left base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. Bowel sounds are normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9110/mm3, and platelet count is 190,000/mm3. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Diaphragmatic rupture is most commonly caused by penetrating injuries, followed by blunt trauma, both of which can be caused by a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Clinical features include chest/abdominal wall bruises, decreased breath sounds due to herniation of abdominal contents into the chest, and respiratory distress. Chest auscultation may reveal bowel sounds. Chest x-ray may show disturbed contour of the hemidiaphragm, displaced abdominal organs, and mediastinal shift, as well as an hourglass sign if abdominal contents are constricted at the defect. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Diaphragmatic ruptures more commonly occur on the left side because the right diaphragm is protected by the liver. Patients may initially be asymptomatic, so this condition is often not diagnosed immediately.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal perforation may occur in a variety of clinical scenarios, including Boerhaave syndrome, blunt and penetrating chest trauma, and iatrogenic esophageal perforation (e.g., following endoscopy). Patients with esophageal perforation present with chest pain, tachycardia, and tachypnea. However, this condition is often associated with additional findings such as fever and crepitus over the chest due to mediastinal emphysema. Unlike in this patient, a chest x-ray typically shows a widened mediastinum. Herniation of the stomach into the thorax is not typically associated with esophageal perforation.

C) INCORRECT:

Flail chest can cause respiratory distress due to detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall, which results from three or more adjacent ribs fractured in two or more places. While flail chest can occur following high-velocity trauma, the absence of rib fractures on this patient's chest x-ray rules this condition out.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view; supine) of patient with a history of trauma

Multiple right rib fractures (red lines) are present, some of which show marked displacement. There is extensive subcutaneous emphysema (examples indicated by arrowheads). The right lung is diffusely opaque (green overlay), likely reflective of pulmonary contusion in view of the trauma history.

White overlay: ribs

D) INCORRECT:

A pneumothorax can occur spontaneously or following trauma such as a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Patients typically present with tachypnea, dyspnea, chest pain, and unilaterally reduced breath sounds. However, a chest x-ray usually shows a pleural line, a sudden change in radiolucency, and an abrupt stop in pulmonary vascular markings. This patient's x-ray findings are not consistent with a pneumothorax.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A thin white line represents the visceral pleura of the left lung (dotted line). No lung markings are seen peripheral to the visceral pleura (green overlay).

The appearance is consistent with a left pneumothorax. There is no evidence of contralateral mediastinal shift, diaphragmatic depression, or ipsilateral intercostal space widening to suggest tension pneumothorax.

E) INCORRECT:

The phrenic nerve innervates the diaphragm via the nerve roots C3, C4, and C5. Phrenic nerve palsy is often iatrogenic (e.g., following supraclavicular block) and may occasionally occur following trauma. This condition leads to ipsilateral elevation of the diaphragm, which affects pulmonary and cardiac function. Patients can present with dyspnea. However, x-ray usually shows elevation of the diaphragm on the affected side and not herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (lateral view)

There is elevation of the left hemidiaphragm (dashed line) with adjacent atelectasis (yellow overlay) of lung parenchyma and underlying dilated bowel (B).

Blue overlay: hardware left humerus; solid line: right hemidiaphragm
questions.hint: This patient, who has just been in a car accident, is in respiratory distress and has chest pain, decreased breath sounds over his left lung, and a chest x-ray that is typical for this condition.

questions.text: The x-ray findings suggest a diaphragmatic rupture. A trauma 'huddle' is called, and morphine is administered for pain. Low-flow oxygen and infusion with 0.9% saline are begun. Five minutes later, pulse is 100/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow may be used to confirm suspected diaphragmatic rupture by showing abdominal contents above the diaphragm. However, a barium swallow test is not routinely used in the diagnosis of traumatic diaphragmatic rupture, as the procedure is lengthier and less precise than other procedures and requires the patient's cooperation. Moreover, traumatic diaphragmatic ruptures are often associated with other injuries such as esophageal tears. If barium, a water-insoluble contrast media, enters the mediastinum through a perforation, it may lead to mediastinitis and subsequent fibrosis. A barium study should therefore only be performed after perforations of the gastrointestinal tract have been ruled out.

B) INCORRECT:

Chest fluoroscopy may be indicated for suspected phrenic nerve palsy or conditions involving decreased lung elasticity (e.g., interstitial lung diseases). However, this patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of diaphragmatic rupture, and his chest x-ray should be followed by a different and more specific imaging technique to confirm the diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

A CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient, who is suspected of having a traumatic diaphragmatic rupture. X-ray findings alone are not sufficient to establish diaphragmatic rupture as the definitive diagnosis, as x-rays only show indirect signs of the injury. Moreover, concomitant injuries should be ruled out. A CT would be able to directly visualize the discontinuity of the affected hemidiaphragm and confirm the diagnosis. Indirect findings include thickening of the diaphragm, elevation of abdominal organs, and herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax.
Image Description:

Chest CT scan after IV contrast medium administration in the lung window, arterial phase, axial section, at the level of the junction at which the superior vena cava meets the right atrium: There is herniation of the abdominal organs into the left thoracic cavity. These are most likely sections of the stomach (St, with air-fluid levels = green areas) and the spleen (Sp). Parts of the parenchyma of the left lung are still visible in the ventral region. The ground-glass opacified, diffuse areas in the right lung (red areas) most likely indicate a small ventilatory disturbance. In addition, there is either a small hemothorax or pleural effusion visible in the right dorsal field (red hatched area). (AA=ascending aorta, DA=descending aorta, LA=left atrium, LV=left ventricle, RA=right atrium, RV=right ventricle, V=superior vena cava)

D) INCORRECT:

ICU admission and observation without any further intervention would be an inappropriate decision for this patient, who requires confirmation of the diaphragmatic rupture and subsequent surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

Emergency surgery is the treatment of choice in patients with confirmed diaphragmatic rupture or those who are hemodynamically unstable. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable and only had an x-ray of the chest, which is not sufficient to establish a definite diagnosis. Therefore, he should undergo further diagnostic testing to confirm the diagnosis before undergoing surgery.

F) INCORRECT:

Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) may be performed to obtain a biopsy, resect thoracic masses, or even to repair a diaphragmatic rupture in some cases. However, the diagnosis should be confirmed in this patient before treatment is initiated.

G) INCORRECT:

MRI of the chest and abdomen can be performed for suspected diaphragmatic injury, as this test is able to directly visualize the discontinuity of the affected hemidiaphragm, which would confirm the diagnosis. However, MRI is not the gold standard in trauma patients since there are other imaging techniques that are faster and almost as precise. MRI is the preferred confirmatory test for pregnant women.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was a restrained passenger. On arrival, she is lethargic and incoherent. She is in respiratory distress. Her pulse is 130/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 88/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%. Examination shows multiple facial lacerations. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.1 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows a fractured left second rib, depression of the left main bronchus, deviation of the nasogastric tube to the right, left pleural effusion, and a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flail chest can manifest with respiratory distress. However, paradoxical chest movement is not present in this patient. Additionally, the chest x-ray shows only one fractured rib, and a widened mediastinum is not associated with flail chest, making it an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

B) INCORRECT:

Diaphragmatic rupture commonly results from blunt or penetrating trauma and occurs more often on the left than on the right side (as the liver protects against a rupture on the right). The condition can manifest with respiratory distress and decreased breath sounds. However, x-ray findings typically show herniation of abdominal organs like the stomach and colon, causing an hourglass appearance rather than a widened mediastinum.
Image Description:

AP chest X-ray of a 29-year-old patient with chest trauma after a motor-vehicle crash: the tip of the central venous catheter on the right side (black arrows) projects onto the right atrium. The left hemidiaphragm (black dotted line) is much higher than the right one. The stomach is located within the thorax, as can be seen by the circled gastric bubble. The lung tissue shows streaky densities, which hints towards intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The combination of these findings most likely indicates a ruptured diaphragm with a stomach herniated into the thoracic cavity.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary contusion typically occurs after blunt trauma and can manifest with tachycardia, respiratory distress, and hypoxia. However, it does not commonly present with dullness on percussion. Additionally, the chest x-ray typically shows patchy alveolar infiltrates and not a widened mediastinum, as described above.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window) following trauma to the chest

Areas of ground glass and consolidation in both lungs are the result of pulmonary contusion (green overlay). Ovoid traumatic lacerations in the left lung contain opaque blood (red overlay). Two of the lacerations also contain air, producing air-fluid levels (dashed line). A pneumothorax is present anteriorly in the right hemithorax (blue overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Traumatic bronchial rupture often results from high-velocity blunt chest wall trauma and can manifest with respiratory distress. However, it is typically associated with pneumothorax and subcutaneous emphysema features not present in this woman.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.

Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

E) CORRECT:

A widened mediastinum, esophageal deviation, depression of the left main bronchus, and hemothorax (suggested by left pleural effusion) are consistent with thoracic aortic rupture (TAR). TAR can be traumatic (e.g., due to high-velocity blunt chest wall trauma) or spontaneous (e.g., following aortic dissection). Only around 20% of patients with blunt traumatic aortic injuries survive long enough to reach the hospital; therefore, immediate resuscitation and prompt surgical repair of the thoracic aorta is required in patients with suggestive findings (e.g., symptoms of respiratory distress, features of hemorrhagic shock).
Image Description:

CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)

There is extravasation of contrast (red overlay) from the nonaneurysmal atherosclerotic descending thoracic aorta (bright green overlay), with surrounding hematoma (green striped overlay).

F) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade results from conditions such as pericarditis, chest trauma, malignancies, or kidney dysfunction. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with respiratory distress. This patient has hypotension, but she does not have the jugular venous distention or muffled heart sounds that would be expected in an individual with cardiac tamponade (Becks triad). Additionally, in contrast to this vignette, x-ray findings of cardiac tamponade would typically include an enlarged cardiac silhouette.
Image Description:

Chest X-ray (PA view) of a patient with a history of pericarditis and clinical findings of tamponade

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged (globular water bottle-shape; enlargement highlighted by green-hatched overlay) due to pericardial effusion.

G) INCORRECT:

While a tension pneumothorax can manifest with tachycardia and hypoxia, the lung is typically hyperresonant and not dull to percussion. Additionally, although mediastinal shift is seen on the chest x-ray of tension pneumothorax, absent lung markings would also be expected and there would not be a widened mediastinum.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A large pneumothorax (green overlay) has resulted in collapse of the right lung along the mediastinum (edge marked by white dashed line). No bronchovascular markings are seen in the right hemithorax. Additionally, the mediastinum has shifted to the contralateral left side (blue line and arrows), the right hemidiaphragm is depressed (red line and arrow), and the right intercostal spaces are widened (example indicated by white arrows).

These findings are characteristic of tension pneumothorax.
questions.hint: This condition should always be considered in patients presenting with respiratory distress and signs of developing shock after trauma from rapid deceleration (e.g., high-speed motor vehicle collision). The x-ray findings are highly suggestive of the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after falling and hitting his left flank on a concrete block. On arrival, he has severe left-sided chest pain. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 32 years. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and a multivitamin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.5째C (99.5째F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 17/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows multiple abrasions on his left flank and trunk. The left lateral chest wall is tender to palpation and bony crepitus is present. The remainder of the examination, including cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination, shows no abnormalities. Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative. An x-ray of the chest shows nondisplaced fractures of the left 4th and 5th ribs and clear lung fields bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admission and surveillance in the intensive care unit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Continuous positive airway pressure is indicated for refractory atelectasis following rib fractures. It is not needed as an initial preventive measure for rib fractures without refractory atelectasis, especially since it can cause patient discomfort, gastric distention, hypoventilation, and barotrauma.

B) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotic therapy could be considered for prevention of wound infection if the patient's rib fractures involved open, dirty wounds. However, there is no mention of these findings in the vignette, and antibiotic prophylaxis does not play a role in the prevention of pneumonia following rib fractures.

C) INCORRECT:

Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary in the treatment of severe or complicated rib fracture cases, especially in cases involving flail chest. But flail chest is a complication involving three or more rib fractures. In addition, this patient does not show the paradoxical chest movement typical of flail chest, nor does he have evidence of respiratory distress (e.g., hypoxemia). Although he has shallow breathing, it is most likely due to the pain he is experiencing.

D) INCORRECT:

Admission and surveillance in the intensive care unit may be warranted in older patients with 6 rib fractures, or in those with evidence of complications such as pneumothorax or hemothorax. This patient's chest x-ray shows only two fractured ribs and clear lung fields bilaterally, ruling out pneumothorax or hemothorax.

E) CORRECT:

Conservative fracture management is recommended for patients who have < 3 rib fractures and no evidence of fracture displacement, complications of rib fractures, or other traumatic fractures. In patients with a rib fracture, the pain accompanying chest wall expansion can cause reflex hypoventilation and cough reflex suppression. Adequate pain control is important in preventing hypoventilation and its sequelae (e.g., atelectasis). NSAIDs are most commonly used in these patients, and can also be combined with opioids or intercostal nerve blocks if necessary.

Hospital admission is generally warranted in patients with 3 rib fractures, displaced rib fractures, signs of flail chest, or other complications of rib fractures (e.g., severe pulmonary contusions, renal laceration, splenic laceration). Rib fractures that cause pneumothorax or hemothorax may warrant tube thoracostomy. For falls in older individuals, a workup to identify risk factors for falls would be required.

F) INCORRECT:

Open reduction and internal fixation may be considered for treatment of some rib fractures, particularly those that cause flail chest or chest wall deformities. But flail chest is a complication involving three or more rib fractures. In addition, this patient does not show the paradoxical chest movement typical of flail chest, nor does he have evidence of respiratory distress (e.g., hypoxemia). Although he has shallow breathing, it is most likely due to the pain he is experiencing.
questions.hint: This patient has traumatic fracture of two ribs and requires treatment to prevent atelectasis.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. On arrival, he is alert, has mild chest pain, and minimal shortness of breath. He has one episode of vomiting in the hospital. His temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over his trunk and right upper extremity. There are coarse breath sounds over the right lung base. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallop. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. He subsequently develops increasing shortness of breath. Arterial blood gas analysis on 60% oxygen shows:


pH
7.36


pCO2
39 mm Hg


pO2
68 mm Hg


HCO3-

18 mEq/L


O2 saturation
81%


An x-ray of the chest shows patchy, irregular infiltrates over the right lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blunt trauma to the thorax (e.g., mild chest pain and mild dyspnea on admission) can result in rib fractures or injury to lobar bronchi, and thereby cause a pneumothorax, which also manifests with dyspnea and hypoxemia. However, the classic findings in pneumothorax (e.g., decreased breath sounds, hyperresonance on the affected side, increased radiolucency on chest x-ray) are missing.

B) INCORRECT:

Tracheobronchial injury (TBI) has many causes, including trauma to the chest or neck, deceleration injury, and/or inhalation of hot smoke and noxious gases (usually in association with burns). In the case of TBI due to blunt trauma, injury usually occurs within 2 cm of the carina or at the origin of lobar bronchi. In such a scenario, TBI would manifest with acute dyspnea, as well as clinical features of subcutaneous emphysema (e.g., palpable crepitus), pneumomediastinum (e.g., Hamman crunch), and/or pneumothorax (e.g., decreased breath sounds, hyperresonant percussion note). The absence of characteristic clinical and radiological findings, as well as the delayed onset of dyspnea in this patient, makes the diagnosis of TBI unlikely.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.

Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

C) CORRECT:

Pulmonary contusion is the most common lung injury following blunt injury to the chest wall (e.g., during a motor vehicle accident). Damage to the capillaries in the lung parenchyma results in pulmonary edema and/or bleeding within contused lung tissue, which appears as a patchy infiltrate on chest x-ray. Excessive fluid administration worsens pulmonary edema, as the damaged capillaries leak fluid into the lungs.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with pulmonary embolism may present with acute dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and a localized patchy infiltrate on a chest x-ray. In the case of this 19-year-old man who was involved in a car accident, the most likely cause of pulmonary embolism is a fat embolus, which usually arises following a pelvic or long bone fracture. But the absence of a fracture makes a fat embolism unlikely. The x-ray findings of pulmonary embolism also tend to appear 1224 hours after the event, not within an hour of trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

The most important risk factor for aspiration pneumonia in a polytrauma patient is loss of consciousness, which impairs the gag and cough reflexes. However, this patient never lost consciousness. Patients with aspiration pneumonia may also present with dyspnea, hypoxemia, and a patchy infiltrate on chest x-ray. Moreover, clinical and radiological features of acute aspiration pneumonia usually develop over the course of 1224 hours after aspiration and not immediately upon arrival at the hospital.

F) INCORRECT:

A massive hemothorax can manifest with acute dyspnea, hypoxemia, tachycardia, and hypotension. However, a hemothorax appears on a chest x-ray as a singular and continuous collection of fluid in the dependent portion of the thorax, not as patchy infiltrates.

G) INCORRECT:

Acute respiratory distress (ARDS) also manifests with acute dyspnea, hypoxemia, and alveolar or interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray. However, ARDS arises within the context of a severe inflammatory reaction that typically develops over the course of 1236 hours after the initial insult. The appearance of dyspnea and hypoxia within an hour of the event, as well as the localization of the infiltrate in the right lung base (ARDS affects the entire lung parenchyma), makes ARDS highly unlikely. ARDS can occur as a complication of this patient's condition.
questions.hint: This patient developed dyspnea and hypoxia that worsens after giving fluids, indicating damage to the pulmonary vasculature.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling 7 feet onto a flat-top wooden post. On arrival, he is in severe pain and breathing rapidly. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. There is an impact wound in the left fourth intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Auscultation shows tracheal deviation to the right and absent breath sounds over the left lung. There is dullness to percussion over the left chest. Neck veins are flat. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray is shown. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade may manifest with tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. However, neck veins would be distended instead of collapsed, and heart sounds would be muffled on auscultation. Also, tracheal deviation would not be present in an isolated case of cardiac tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchial rupture would manifest with subcutaneous emphysema and hemoptysis. Clinical features of a pneumothorax such as hyperresonant lung fields would also be present in distal tracheobronchial tree injuries. The absence of any of these findings suggests a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.

Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

C) INCORRECT:

Tension pneumothorax may manifest with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, decreased breath sounds on the affected side, and deviation of the trachea to the opposite side. However, neck veins would be distended instead of collapsed because the mediastinal shift that occurs with a tension pneumothorax compresses the superior vena cava. Also, lung fields on the affected side would be hyperresonant instead of dull on percussion.

D) INCORRECT:

A flail chest could manifest with respiratory distress and tachypnea. A patient with flail chest classically exhibits paradoxical movement of a part of the chest wall on respiration. Although this sign may be absent due to respiratory splinting, a mediastinal shift (tracheal deviation), decreased breath sounds, and a dull note on percussion are not characteristic signs of a flail chest. The absence of bony crepitus also suggests that the patient does not have a rib fracture. A different diagnosis must be considered.
Image Description:

Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

E) CORRECT:

Hemothorax can develop following blunt chest trauma. This patient exhibits all the signs and symptoms of a massive hemothorax, i.e., tachycardia, hypotension, tachypnea, flat neck veins, decreased breath sounds, and dullness on percussion on the affected side, as well as tracheal deviation to the opposite side. A hemothorax must be drained in most cases because blood in the pleural cavity may clot if not evacuated, resulting in a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection). Treatment usually consists of chest tube insertion into the 4th5th intercostal space at the midaxillary line in order to allow the blood to drain away and improve lung ventilation. Conservative management may be considered to treat small hemothoraces in consultation with a specialist but has a significant failure rate.
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray shows left-sided opacity and blunting of the costophrenic angle.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and is in severe pain. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. Examination shows superficial abrasions and diffuse crepitus at the left shoulder level. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The upper part of the left chest wall moves inward during inspiration. Breath sounds are absent on the left. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diaphragmatic rupture can occur after high-energy trauma and, in case of herniation of abdominal organs into the chest, cause respiratory distress with decreased breath sounds in the affected hemithorax. However, in such a scenario, bowel sounds would be heard during auscultation of the affected hemithorax. In addition, diaphragmatic rupture would not explain the paradoxical motion of a segment of the left chest wall.

B) INCORRECT:

Phrenic nerve damage may be caused by trauma, malignancy, or surgery and result in partial or complete paralysis of the diaphragm. Phrenic nerve paralysis may be asymptomatic or manifest with dyspnea. Unilateral phrenic nerve paralysis leads to the paradoxical upward movement of the affected hemidiaphragm. The condition would not explain the paradoxical motion of a segment of the left chest wall.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade typically presents with hypotension, tachycardia, jugular venous distention, and pulsus paradoxus. Although this patient is hypotensive and tachycardic, no other signs of cardiac tamponade are present. In addition, cardiac tamponade would not explain the paradoxical motion of the chest wall.

D) INCORRECT:

Sternal fracture classically occurs after blunt anterior chest trauma such as that caused by a motor vehicle collision. It is often associated with myocardial contusions. Although this patient may have an associated sternal fracture, this type of injury does not sufficiently explain his respiratory distress and the paradoxical movement of the chest wall.

E) CORRECT:

A flail chest is the detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall as a result of 3 adjacent rib fractures in 2 places. This floating rib cage segment is decoupled from the chest wall and causes paradoxical chest movement. Upon inspiration, as the intrathoracic pressure drops, the unstable segment will be pulled inwards by the negative pressure, and during expiration, the floating segment moves outward. This condition usually results from high-energy blunt trauma to the chest (e.g., motor vehicle collision). Patients with flail chest commonly present with features of respiratory distress (e.g., dyspnea, tachypnea), which can be due to hypoventilation (as a result of pain), pulmonary contusions, pneumothorax, and/or hemothorax.
Image Description:

Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.
questions.hint: Mechanical ventilation with positive end-expiratory pressure helps counter the paradoxical breathing described here.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left shoulder pain after falling from a height of approximately 10 feet while rock climbing 5 hours ago. He initially thought the pain would resolve with rest but it became more severe over the last 2 hours. Last year while rock climbing he fell onto his right shoulder and needed a sling to fix it. He has psoriasis. His only medication is topical clobetasol. His pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/70 mm Hg. Examination shows full passive and active range of motion of the left shoulder. There is no tenderness to palpation at the acromioclavicular joint. There are silvery plaques over both knees and elbows. Abdominal examination shows severe tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant with voluntary guarding. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes are within the reference range. Chest x-ray is normal. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no evidence of free intraperitoneal fluid. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Serial vital signs for at least nine hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The severity of abdominal injury determines whether hemodynamically stable patients can be managed nonoperatively with serial monitoring of vital signs. Although unsupported by high-quality evidence, serial monitoring of vital signs for a period of 9 hours without imaging may be a reasonable approach following trauma for hemodynamically stable patients with a low risk of abdominal injury. This patient, however, has fallen from a height of 10 feet and has left upper quadrant pain and guarding, as well as a positive Kehr sign, all of which indicate a splenic injury that requires additional abdominal imaging.

B) CORRECT:

Abdominal CT with contrast is the most appropriate next step, following a negative FAST scan, in the management of a hemodynamically stable patient with a suspected splenic injury. CT scan has greater specificity than ultrasonography for diagnosing splenic lacerations because it can visualize the vasculature and parenchyma of the spleen in high resolution. Findings on the CT scan are used to grade splenic injury and guide further management. CT scan can also rule out other concomitant injuries in cases of abdominal trauma, especially injuries involving retroperitoneal structures.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane; portal venous phase) of a 24 year-old patient after a high-speed front-impact crash

The spleen has an irregular contour (dashed outline) and heterogeneous enhancement. Intrasplenic low-attenuation rounded and linear areas are sites of laceration and hematoma formation. Multiple small high-density foci along the inferior aspect of the spleen indicate contrast extravasation (arrows) from active bleeding.

Hemorrhage (green overlay) into the peritoneal space extends from the spleen inferiorly along the paracolic gutter. Hemorrhagic fluid is also seen along the liver (yellow overlay) and within the right paracolic gutter and pelvis (yellow overlay).

Multiple thoracic spine fractures (examples indicated by arrowheads) are accompanied by paravertebral hematoma (red overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is a procedure that can be used in patients with blunt abdominal trauma to determine the presence of blood within the peritoneum. DPL should only be considered in hemodynamically unstable patients who have an inconclusive FAST scan. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable and a FAST scan was negative for free intraperitoneal fluid. In addition, although highly sensitive, DPL has largely fallen out of favor because it is an invasive procedure; it may, however, be necessary in some cases (e.g., in resource-poor settings).

D) INCORRECT:

Shoulder radiographs are the first-line imaging modality in the diagnostic workup of traumatic shoulder injury (i.e., clavicle, proximal humerus, or scapula fractures; acromioclavicular or glenohumeral dislocations). However, the combination of left upper quadrant tenderness and guarding, onset of left shoulder pain a few hours after the initial trauma, and a normal shoulder joint examination indicates that this patient's acute shoulder pain is most likely the result of referred pain due to diaphragmatic irritation (Kehr sign) rather than a traumatic shoulder injury.

E) INCORRECT:

An exploratory laparotomy is a surgical procedure that encompasses examination and treatment of the intraabdominal cavity for sources of bleeding in patients with blunt abdominal trauma. It is typically performed in hemodynamically unstable patients following the confirmation of free intraperitoneal fluid. This patient is hemodynamically stable and initial diagnostic imaging shows no evidence of intraabdominal bleeding. Therefore, an exploratory laparotomy is not appropriate at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Left upper quadrant tenderness and guarding, the onset of left shoulder pain a few hours after the initial trauma, as well as a normal shoulder joint examination, indicate that the shoulder pain in this patient most likely results from referred pain due to diaphragmatic irritation (Kehr sign), and is not the result of a traumatic shoulder injury. If shoulder injury were suspected, a shoulder MRI could be useful to image soft tissue of the shoulder such as the rotator cuff and acromioclavicular ligaments. However, MRI is not the first-line of imaging in a patient with a suspected traumatic shoulder injury.
questions.hint: Left upper quadrant abdominal pain, voluntary guarding, and referred shoulder pain (Kehr sign) in a patient who has fallen from a significant height indicates splenic injury.

questions.text: A 27-year-old soldier is brought to the emergency department of a military hospital 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle accident during a training exercise. He was an unrestrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and chest pain. He appears anxious. His temperature is 37.0째C (98.6째F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows bruising on the chest, extremities, and abdomen. The lungs are clear to auscultation. He has normal heart sounds and flat neck veins. The abdomen is flat, soft, and mildly tender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. High-flow oxygen and intravenous fluid therapy are initiated. A focused ultrasonographic assessment (FAST scan) shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is indicated for the treatment of cardiac tamponade, which can occur following trauma (due to a hemopericardium) and cause chest pain, dyspnea, and a widened mediastinum. However, patients with cardiac tamponade typically have muffled heart sounds, hemodynamic instability, and distended (rather than flat) neck veins. The normal FAST scan and the absence of an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest x-ray make a hemopericardium unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Blunt force aortic injuries range from small intimal tears and intramural hematomas to aortic rupture. Contrast-enhanced CT angiography (CECT angiography) is indicated for the diagnosis of aortic injury in hemodynamically stable patients and should be performed if the patient has symptoms suggestive of aortic injury (e.g., chest pain), a history of high-energy trauma, or features that suggest aortic injury on the FAST scan (e.g., hemothorax) or chest x-ray (e.g., mediastinal widening, aortic knob loss). CECT angiography has high sensitivity and specificity, can screen for additional vascular injuries (e.g., abdominal aortic injury), and provides anatomical information for planning surgical management. Patients who are hemodynamically unstable should be urgently evaluated with transesophageal echocardiography in the operating room.

C) INCORRECT:

Although aortography, which is performed using vascular catheterization, was previously used to evaluate for aortic pathology, less invasive modalities that are more readily available are now preferred.

D) INCORRECT:

A transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) to identify thoracic aortic injury is indicated in patients who are hemodynamically unstable and cannot be transported safely for other imaging modalities. A hemodynamically stable patient requires a different imaging modality that provides more detailed anatomical information.

E) INCORRECT:

A chest tube can be used to treat patients with a pneumothorax or hemothorax. However, this patient's chest x-ray and FAST scan do not indicate the presence of either of these conditions.

F) INCORRECT:

Intubation with positive pressure ventilation may be indicated if the patient has evidence of a flail chest or is developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). This patient's chest x-ray finding suggests a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: The patient sustained a deceleration injury and has mediastinal widening on chest x-ray, suggesting blunt thoracic aortic injury.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) results are negative. An ECG shows absent P waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tracheobronchial injuries can occur as a result of severe blunt chest trauma and also present with hypotension, dyspnea, or tachypnea. However, they are usually associated with bloody oral secretions, subcutaneous emphysema, and/or pneumothorax with a positive Hamman's sign.

B) CORRECT:

In the context of a serious motor vehicle collision, this patient's hypotension and tachycardia refractive to fluid resuscitation, including vasopressors, combined with atrial fibrillation on ECG and a negative FAST, are highly suspicious for cardiac contusion. Cardiac contusions may manifest with clinical features ranging from asymptomatic arrhythmias to rapidly fatal cardiac rupture. Blunt chest trauma and/or sudden deceleration can lead to decreased contractility and arrhythmias due to injury to cardiac myocytes and pacemaker cells. Decreased contractility directly contributes to cardiogenic shock with decreased cardiac output and hypotension, as in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Splenic rupture most often occurs in the setting of blunt abdominal trauma and can result in hemodynamic instability secondary to massive intraabdominal blood loss. However, an intraabdominal hemorrhage large enough to lead to deterioration would be seen on the FAST exam.

D) INCORRECT:

A hemothorax might manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, diminished/absent breath sounds, decreased tactile fremitus, dullness on percussion, and flat neck veins. It may also be associated with a raised jugular venous pressure. In severe cases of hemothorax, blood loss into the thoracic cavity can lead to hemorrhagic shock, with subsequent tachycardia and hypotension. However, a hemothorax is distinctly identifiable on chest x-ray or on ultrasound as part of the FAST exam. No signs of internal bleeding are apparent on this patient's FAST exam and the physical exam findings (bibasilar crackles, soft abdomen) make a significant hemothorax even more unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

An aortic dissection may occur as the result of rapid deceleration (e.g., in a motor vehicle accident) and typically manifests with severe tearing chest pain that may radiate to different parts of the body. Aortic dissection is associated with hypotension either if the dissection involves the ascending aorta resulting in cardiac tamponade and/or aortic regurgitation, or if it results in aortic rupture and hemorrhage into the mediastinum. On the FAST exam, however, aortic rupture would be apparent as free fluid above the diaphragm, with secondary cardiac tamponade as fluid accumulates in the pericardium. Moreover, secondary aortic regurgitation severe enough to affect the patient's vitals would be heard on auscultation.

F) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary contusions can occur in the setting of chest trauma and result in chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, and hypoxia as bruising of the lung impairs gas exchange. Symptoms may then worsen following fluid administration as fluid accumulates in the damaged lung. While this patient does have chest pain and tachypnea and deteriorated after receiving fluids, pulmonary contusion would be less likely to cause the arrhythmia or fluid- and vasopressor-resistant hypotension that proved fatal in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade due to hemopericardium can occur after chest trauma due to cardiac wall rupture or aortic dissection of the ascending aorta, with accumulation of blood around the heart. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with rapidly developing hypotension and tachycardia following chest trauma, and show elevated jugular venous pressure (as part of Beck triad). However, patients with a cardiac tamponade will have a pulsus paradoxus, characteristically muffled heart sounds, and the FAST exam will show fluid around the heart.
questions.hint: While hypotension following acute trauma should raise concern for blood loss, this patient's negative FAST exam makes intraabdominal or intrathoracic bleeding less likely. Instead, his profound hypotension despite an apparently normal volume status, the bibasilar lung crackles, and elevated jugular venous pressure potentially indicate cardiogenic shock.

questions.text:
Ten days after a motor vehicle collision, a 28-year-old man develops jaundiced skin. Upon initial presentation for his injuries, the patient was taken for an emergency laparotomy, which revealed significant internal hemorrhage from blunt abdominal trauma to the spleen. He required rapid transfusion with a total of 7 units of packed red blood cells. He has recovered well from the procedure until this morning, when he began to develop jaundiced skin and sclerae. He does not have pruritus. He has had no prior surgeries and takes no other medications. He is sexually active with one female partner. Prior to the accident, he drank 4 beers per day. His vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination is limited due to pain. There are no palpable abdominal masses. There is a midline surgical scar with no erythema, purulence, or drainage. He has healing abrasions on the upper left side of his face and bruises over the anterior abdomen. CT scan shows a resolving hematoma in the peritoneal cavity. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.7 g/dL


Hematocrit
30%


Leukocyte count
7000/mm3



Platelet count
135,000/mm3



Serum



 Total bilirubin
3.9 mg/dL


 Indirect bilirubin

3.7 mg/dL


 Direct bilirubin
0.2 mg/dL


 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
60 U/L


 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
92 U/L


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's jaundice?

choices.text: Decreased hepatic uptake of unconjugated bilirubin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Biliary obstruction, which can be caused by choledocholithiasis, pancreatic masses, or primary sclerosing cholangitis, leads to an increase in conjugated, rather than unconjugated, bilirubin. In addition, blunt abdominal trauma rarely causes biliary obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

The liver and spleen are the most commonly injured solid organs in patients who have sustained blunt abdominal trauma. Though this patient has a mild increase in transaminase concentrations, which may indicate some injury to the liver, hepatocellular injury generally results in a mixed conjugated and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to interference in uptake, conjugation, and excretion of bilirubin.

C) CORRECT:

Reabsorption of blood from a hematoma (e.g., in trauma patients or postsurgical patients) involves the breakdown of hemoglobin, which is metabolized into bilirubin before being transported to the liver to be conjugated with glucuronic acid to become water-soluble. Increased formation of bilirubin results in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Intrahepatic cholestasis is caused by various conditions, including viral hepatitis, alcohol-associated hepatitis, and primary biliary cholangitis. Intrahepatic cholestasis causes an increase in conjugated bilirubin, not unconjugated bilirubin.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired conjugation of bilirubin is seen in patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome and Gilbert syndrome, both of which are congenital conditions that impair intrahepatic conjugation of bilirubin with glucuronic acid. Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a rare disease that typically causes severe jaundice and neurologic impairment in newborns; this condition is unlikely in this adult patient with asymptomatic jaundice. Gilbert syndrome can manifest later in life, but this patient's recent history of blunt abdominal trauma with a resolving hematoma on CT scan makes another cause of jaundice more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased hepatic uptake of unconjugated bilirubin can occur in patients with congestive heart failure, portosystemic shunts, and, rarely, Gilbert syndrome. Although these conditions can also cause an isolated increase in unconjugated bilirubin, they are unlikely in this young patient who has no history of cardiovascular or hepatobiliary disease.
questions.hint: This patient has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia 10 days after significant internal hemorrhage from blunt abdominal trauma. The underlying cause involves reabsorption of the hematoma in his peritoneal cavity.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient appears to be in moderate respiratory distress and is cradling his upper left arm in his right arm. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 36.7째C (98째F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 25/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 108/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen via a non-rebreather face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows multiple bruises on the left anterior thoracic wall. Jugular venous pulsation is measured at 3 cm above the sternal angle with the head of the bed elevated at 30 degrees. The trachea is at the midline. On inspiration, his left chest wall moves inwards while his right chest wall is expanding. There is pain to palpation and crepitus over his left anterior ribs. A CT scan confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Needle thoracostomy is performed if the patient has a tension pneumothorax. Although rib fractures can cause a pneumothorax, the absence of tracheal deviation and increased jugular venous pressure makes a tension pneumothorax unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Rib fractures inhibit deep breathing because of the pain accompanying chest wall expansion. The flail segment further increases the work of breathing and restricts lung volume changes by moving in the direction opposite to thoracic wall movement. The initial management of a flail chest consists of adequate analgesia and supplemental oxygen therapy. Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is indicated if the patient has evidence of respiratory failure. PPV directly assists with alveolar ventilation and gas exchange and may have an internal splinting effect on the flail segment. In patients who are alert and fully oriented, noninvasive PPV may be attempted, but this patient with an altered mental status also requires intubation for airway protection.

If the patient with a flail chest has a concomitant pneumothorax, tube thoracostomy should be performed before initiating PPV to prevent a simple pneumothorax from turning into a life-threatening tension pneumothorax.
Image Description:

Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

C) INCORRECT:

Bedside thoracotomy is indicated as a last resort for cardiac arrest or exsanguinating intrathoracic hemorrhage when all other measures have failed. Although this patient shows respiratory compromise and requires urgent intervention, thoracotomy is not an appropriate treatment for a flail chest.

D) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is indicated for a patient with cardiac tamponade, which can occur following trauma as a result of a hemopericardium. The absence of increased jugular venous pressure makes a cardiac tamponade unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical fixation may be indicated for patients with flail chest but would not be the first step in treatment of a patient with respiratory distress who does not respond to O2 supplementation. Indications include gross chest wall deformity and failure to wean the patient off mechanical ventilation, which would be a sign that mechanical ventilation alone does not provide sufficient internal stabilization of the flail segment.
questions.hint: Paradoxical chest movement (inward movement of the chest wall during inspiration) indicates a flail chest, which is a detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to  3 adjacent rib fractures in  2 places.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision where she was the unrestrained driver. She was found thrown across the dashboard of the car. On arrival, she appears lethargic. She is unable to provide a history. Her pulse is 133/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 82/54 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm laceration over the right upper extremity. There are multiple bruises over the chest and abdomen. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An intravenous infusion of 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation is inappropriate in the management of this patient, who presents after blunt abdominal trauma with altered mental status, multiple bruises, and unstable vital signs. This patient needs urgent workup and treatment for the cause of her hemodynamic instability.

B) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy is the first step in managing blunt abdominal trauma if signs of peritoneal irritation are present. However, this patient has no signs of peritoneal irritation, and other diagnostic approaches must first be considered to investigate why this patient is hemodynamically unstable. In the case that no other diagnostic resources are readily available, exploratory laparotomy should be performed if there is high clinical suspicion of intraperitoneal hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen would not be the next best step for managing this unstable patient. Although a CT scan can also show the presence of a hemoperitoneum, it takes time and unnecessarily exposes the patient to radiation when other more rapid diagnostic studies are available.

D) CORRECT:

Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is an essential component of management for blunt abdominal trauma. This patient presents after a motor vehicle collision and is hemodynamically unstable, which is concerning for intraperitoneal bleeding. The FAST exam screens for free fluid, especially blood, in the right upper quadrant, left upper quadrant, pericardial space, and pelvis.

E) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) would not be the most appropriate next step because other less invasive and more readily available diagnostic studies should be available to assess for intraabdominal bleeding. A DPL can be considered when other diagnostic studies are unavailable or equivocal.
questions.hint: Intraabdominal bleeding should be ruled out in an unstable trauma patient initially with a noninvasive, easily accessible imaging modality.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after losing control of his bicycle and colliding with a parked car. He was thrown over the handlebars and hit the ground. He reports that he was wearing a helmet and that he did not lose consciousness. He has mild pain in his legs and on his right side but says that he feels well otherwise. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There are a few bruises over his right chest, flank, and lower extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is tenderness to palpation over the right thorax. There is no pelvic instability. The external genitalia appear normal. Complete blood count, prothrombin time, and serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. A voided urine specimen is clear. Microscopic examination of the urine shows 85 RBCs/hpf. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no free intra-abdominal fluid. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 11th rib on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placement of a suprapubic catheter is indicated to relieve and prevent urinary retention. Indications of suprapubic catheter placement include urethral injuries requiring surgical repair, urethral obstruction, acute prostatitis, or prostate cancer in which transurethral catheterization is contraindicated or technically not possible. Microscopic hematuria, as seen in this patient, can be a sign of a mild urethral injury, but it would need to be confirmed before a suprapubic catheterization is considered. In addition, the patient has no signs of urinary retention such as abdominal pain or a palpable suprapubic mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography (IVP) is used for the evaluation of possible renal disease, detection of renal stones, or to assess potential contrast extravasation if contrast-enhanced CT images are not diagnostic. IVP was formerly a preferred imaging modality for renal trauma; however, a different test has supplanted IVP as the imaging modality of choice.

C) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy after BAT is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients with signs of peritonitis and hemodynamically stable patients with evidence of free intra-abdominal fluid on imaging. This patient is hemodynamically stable and focused assessment with sonography for trauma is normal.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with BAT, a CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating abdominal injuries, including those of the genitourinary tract. BAT is a major cause of mortality and requires a high degree of clinical suspicion, even if a patient's initial presentation does not suggest any significant intra-abdominal injury. This patient with suspected renal trauma requires a CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis to establish the diagnosis and further assess the degree of trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Retrograde urethrocystography is used to evaluate the lower genitourinary tract and urinary bladder. It is indicated in patients with gross hematuria or blood at the urethral meatus following a pelvic fracture. This patient, however, only has microscopic hematuria and no signs of a pelvic fracture. Therefore, a retrograde urethrocystography is not indicated at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Observation and follow-up may be appropriate in patients who are hemodynamically stable and have no signs of traumatic injury. Although mild microscopic hematuria is common following BAT and does not necessarily indicate genitourinary injury, this patient has evidence of a right rib fracture, which is concerning for a renal injury. Therefore, observation and follow-up would not be an appropriate next step.
questions.hint: The combination of a fracture of the 11th rib on the right side and microscopic hematuria in a patient with a history of blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) should raise concern for renal injury.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling down a flight of stairs. On arrival, she has shortness of breath, right-sided chest pain, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and right shoulder pain. She is otherwise healthy. She takes no medications. She appears pale. Her temperature is 37째C (98.6째F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Examination shows several ecchymoses over the right chest. There is tenderness to palpation over the right chest wall and right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Bowel sounds are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neck veins are flat. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The spleen is one of the most commonly injured organs during blunt abdominal trauma. Severe hemorrhage associated with splenic laceration often results in tachycardia and hypotension. However, rather than right-sided pain, patients with splenic injury usually experience left-sided abdominal pain and left shoulder pain (Kehr sign).

B) INCORRECT:

Small bowel perforation is a possible sequela of blunt abdominal trauma such as this patient's fall. While penetrating trauma may lead to immediate bowel injury and intestinal leakage, blunt abdominal trauma typically results in necrosis and delayed perforation after several days, making the diagnosis unlikely in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumothorax may occur secondary to blunt chest trauma such as falls. It manifests with dyspnea and ipsilateral chest pain, as well as hemodynamic instability in the case of tension pneumothorax (due to mediastinal compression and decreased venous return). However, the physical examination in patients with pneumothorax typically shows reduced or absent breath sounds over the affected lung. Tension pneumothorax would also manifest with jugular venous distention rather than the flat neck veins seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

A liver hematoma commonly results from blunt abdominal trauma such as falls. This patient has the typical features of liver injury, including ecchymoses over the right chest, pain in the right upper quadrant and the right chest, referred pain to the right shoulder (due to diaphragmatic irritation), and hemodynamic instability. After stabilizing this patient, a focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) should be performed to assess for free fluid in the abdomen.

E) INCORRECT:

Duodenal hematoma is a common injury in children who suffer blunt abdominal trauma. In children, the abdominal wall is thinner and less developed, and inner organs, especially the duodenum, take up a larger portion of the body relative to height, making them more prone to injury. Typical symptoms, such as epigastric pain, bilious emesis, and an upper abdominal mass, result from the associated small bowel obstruction. The absence of these symptoms in combination with the patient's age makes this diagnosis less likely.
questions.hint: This patient's injury involves one of the most commonly injured organs following blunt trauma.

questions.text: A 27-year-old-man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a motorcycle accident. He lost control at high speed and was thrown forward onto the handlebars. On arrival, he is alert and responsive. He has abdominal pain and superficial lacerations on his left arm. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tender, erythematous area over his epigastrium. The abdomen is soft and non-distended. A CT scan of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Treatment with analgesics is begun, the lacerations are cleaned and dressed, and the patient is discharged home after 2 hours of observation. Four days later, the patient returns to the emergency department with gradually worsening upper abdominal pain, fever, poor appetite, and vomiting. His pulse is 91/min and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pancreatic ductal injury can occur in cases of blunt abdominal trauma when the pancreas is compressed against the vertebral bodies, commonly from seatbelt or handlebar injuries as a result of motor vehicle or bicycle accidents. Signs and symptoms of ductal injury may resemble those of acute pancreatitis and may likewise take several days to manifest. This explains the often delayed presentation and diagnosis of pancreatic injuries such as laceration, contusion, or rupture. Although a CT scan is a key imaging modality in patients with blunt abdominal trauma, it has poor sensitivity for early detection of traumatic pancreatic injuries.

B) INCORRECT:

Liver hematoma is one of the most common complications of blunt abdominal trauma. This condition is typically identified on abdominal CT scan posttrauma. In addition, fever and a delayed onset of symptoms are not typical features of a liver hematoma.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with IV contrast; axial plane) of a patient involved in a motor vehicle crash

Two biconvex hypodense hematomas (1, green overlay) are seen between the hepatic capsule and parenchyma.

2: spleen; 3: liver; 4: IVC (inferior vena cava)

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic dissection may occur as a complication of blunt trauma with rapid deceleration (e.g., in a motor vehicle accident). This condition typically manifests with the acute onset of tearing chest or abdominal pain with radiation to the back, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation.
Image Description:

CT scan of the thorax (axial view)

An intimal flap (dashed line) resulting in a double lumen is seen in the descending aorta. The smaller lumen (true lumen; red overlay) shows high contrast density. The larger lumen (false lumen; green overlay) shows low-contrast density due to delayed enhancement.

This appearance is typical of an aortic dissection.

Arrows: atelectasis; AA: ascending aorta; PA: pulmonary artery

D) INCORRECT:

Abdominal compartment syndrome can be a complication of abdominal trauma. This is secondary to the accumulation of blood causing increased intra-abdominal pressure and ultimately organ dysfunction. Patients usually appear critically ill with tense abdominal distention and hemodynamic instability, which this patient does not have. In addition, CT imaging would typically show intra-abdominal trauma or bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Diaphragmatic rupture manifests with acute onset respiratory distress and decreased breath sounds on the affected side, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation. In addition, abdominal CT imaging would show herniation of intra-abdominal contents into the thorax.
Image Description:

Chest CT scan after IV contrast medium administration in the lung window, arterial phase, axial section, at the level of the junction at which the superior vena cava meets the right atrium: There is herniation of the abdominal organs into the left thoracic cavity. These are most likely sections of the stomach (St, with air-fluid levels = green areas) and the spleen (Sp). Parts of the parenchyma of the left lung are still visible in the ventral region. The ground-glass opacified, diffuse areas in the right lung (red areas) most likely indicate a small ventilatory disturbance. In addition, there is either a small hemothorax or pleural effusion visible in the right dorsal field (red hatched area). (AA=ascending aorta, DA=descending aorta, LA=left atrium, LV=left ventricle, RA=right atrium, RV=right ventricle, V=superior vena cava)

F) INCORRECT:

Splenic rupture is one of the most common injuries from blunt abdominal trauma. Symptoms of splenic rupture are most commonly sudden rather than gradual in onset. Moreover, splenic rupture would have likely been identified on the initial abdominal CT scan posttrauma. In addition, splenic rupture is likely to cause massive intra-abdominal bleeding and hemodynamic instability. Fever, poor appetite, and vomiting would not be expected.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane; portal venous phase) of a 24 year-old patient after a high-speed front-impact crash

The spleen has an irregular contour (dashed outline) and heterogeneous enhancement. Intrasplenic low-attenuation rounded and linear areas are sites of laceration and hematoma formation. Multiple small high-density foci along the inferior aspect of the spleen indicate contrast extravasation (arrows) from active bleeding.

Hemorrhage (green overlay) into the peritoneal space extends from the spleen inferiorly along the paracolic gutter. Hemorrhagic fluid is also seen along the liver (yellow overlay) and within the right paracolic gutter and pelvis (yellow overlay).

Multiple thoracic spine fractures (examples indicated by arrowheads) are accompanied by paravertebral hematoma (red overlay).
