questions.hint: Damage to this retroperitoneal structure should be considered in patients presenting with delayed symptoms after blunt abdominal trauma, even if initial imaging showed normal anatomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. The patient is confused. His pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a hand-sized hematoma on the anterior chest wall. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following structures is most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture is a notorious complication after a myocardial infarction and presents with acute hypotension, new-onset mitral regurgitation, and subsequent pulmonary edema. Rapid deceleration injury in a motor vehicle accident is not associated with papillary muscle rupture.

B) CORRECT:

The aortic isthmus, a physiological narrowing at the final section of the aortic arch, is located just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery and is tethered by the ligamentum arteriosum. It is the most common site of injury due to blunt aortic trauma because it is extremely vulnerable to rapid deceleration injury, which can occur in motor vehicle accidents when the chest smashes against the steering wheel or is abruptly restrained by the seatbelt.

Management aims to assess the severity of injury and includes a CT angiography in hemodynamically stable patients or a TEE if hemodynamically unstable.

C) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, rapid deceleration injury in the setting of a motor vehicle accident can lead to a large aortic tear that extends to the aortic valve. Nevertheless, this is not a common site of injury. Moreover, a diastolic murmur would be heard due to new-onset aortic regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Injury to the inferior vena cava may occur in patients after blunt decelerating trauma, but it is extremely rare. Aside from that, the hematoma seen on the patient's chest would not be typical as injury to the inferior vena cava would likely result in retroperitoneal hematoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Although the coronary arteries may also be affected together with aortic injury, the absence of ST-segment abnormalities on this patient's ECG makes involvement of the left main coronary artery unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of shock (hypotension, tachycardia, altered mental status) after severe blunt chest trauma in the setting of a motor vehicle accident is highly suggestive of blunt thoracic aortic injury.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a bar fight. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the left side of the back. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 12th rib on the left side. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following injuries?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The liver lies in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen deep to the 5th12th ribs. Right-sided rib fractures are commonly associated with liver injury due to direct transmission of force from the causative blow to the liver and/or penetration of the liver by a fractured segment of a rib. This patient has sustained a left-sided 12th rib fracture, making a liver injury unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

A pneumothorax can develop if there is an inlet of air into the pleural cavity. The posterior attachment of the parietal pleura extends to the 12th rib. The inferior border of the lungs extends only to the 10th rib posteriorly but could be injured and result in a pneumothorax if a fractured segment of the 12th rib penetrates the lung parenchyma during deep inspiration. However, another organ that lies in close proximity to the 12th rib is more likely to be injured.

C) INCORRECT:

The colon is a hollow organ that is elastic and compressible. It is rarely injured in blunt force injuries. Although the splenic flexure of the colon lies in the vicinity of the left 12th rib, they are not in direct contact with one another. Colon perforation due to a fractured segment of a rib is unlikely in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The kidneys normally lie in a paraspinal, retroperitoneal position that extends from T12L3. The right kidney is displaced more inferiorly because of the liver. Inferior rib fractures (1012th ribs) are commonly associated with solid organ injuries to the liver, spleen, and/or kidneys. This patient has sustained a fracture of the posterior aspect of the left 12th rib as is evident from the tenderness over his back and the x-ray findings, which makes a kidney laceration the most likely associated injury.

Left lower rib fractures also commonly cause splenic injury (including splenic rupture) due to the proximity of the posterior surface of the spleen to the left 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs. Splenic injury is more common than kidney injury.
Image Description:

The superior pole of the left kidney is located approximately at T12, while the right kidney is located approximately 3 cm lower due to expansion of the liver.

E) INCORRECT:

The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ that extends diagonally from the C-loop of the duodenum, anterior to the L2 vertebra (pancreatic head) to the splenic hilum, anterior to the T12 vertebra (pancreatic tail). The pancreas is well-protected from blunt abdominal trauma because it is surrounded by the liver, spleen, stomach, small intestine, left kidney, and the left lower ribs, which diffuse the transmission of force from the causative blow. A forceful blow to the epigastrium (e.g., from falling on the handlebar of a bike) is more likely to injure the body of the pancreas rather than a posterior blow, which this patient has sustained.
Image Description:

The main pancreatic duct and the common bile duct merge and enter the descending part of the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla. The accessory duct enters at the minor duodenal papilla.

Note: individual ductal anatomy may vary
questions.hint: The lower ribs, also known as floating ribs, are not attached to the sternum. Fractured ribs can damage visceral organs.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after falling off a horse. Her mother reports that she lost consciousness for fewer than 15 seconds. She reports pain in her left shoulder, left flank, and left hip. She has no history of serious illness but had a sore throat, fatigue, and fever for the past week. She does not take any medications. Her pulse is 105/min and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abrasions on the left upper arm, but no signs of fracture or dislocation. Passive and active range of motion of the shoulder, elbow, and wrist are intact. There is abdominal tenderness and guarding in the left upper quadrant. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 5600/mm3, and platelet count is 145,000/mm3. An abdominal ultrasound shows free intra-abdominal fluid in the Douglas pouch. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's sonographic findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain and guarding, shock, and free intra-abdominal fluid after abdominal trauma raise suspicion for small bowel perforation. However, while penetrating abdominal trauma (e.g., gunshot, knife wound) leads to immediate bowel injury and intestinal leakage, blunt abdominal trauma (e.g., this patient's fall) typically results in an intestinal contusion, which slowly develops into necrosis and intestinal rupture after several days. This patient's acute presentation after a fall makes another diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain radiating to the shoulder and abdominal guarding after a fall may raise suspicion for liver hematoma. However, liver hematoma is associated with right upper quadrant pain that radiates to the right shoulder, not left upper quadrant pain radiating to the left shoulder. Moreover, in the absence of liver parenchymal disruption, a liver hematoma is an encapsulated collection of blood and would not present with hemoperitoneum (i.e., blood in the rectovaginal pouch of Douglas).

C) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic laceration may occur in blunt abdominal trauma (e.g., this patient's fall), causing abdominal pain and guarding. However, pancreatic laceration is associated with right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, not left upper quadrant pain that radiates to the left shoulder. Moreover, because the majority of the pancreas is retroperitoneal (only the tail is intraperitoneal), pancreatic laceration is more likely to manifest with a retroperitoneal or peripancreatic hematoma than with blood in the pouch of Douglas.

D) CORRECT:

Left upper quadrant pain radiating to the left shoulder (Kehr sign), abdominal guarding, and hemorrhagic shock (tachycardia, decreased hemoglobin) after blunt abdominal trauma in a patient with a recent history of infectious mononucleosis (IM) is consistent with splenic rupture. IM is associated with splenomegaly, so affected individuals have an increased risk of splenic rupture and are therefore advised to avoid physical activity for at least 3 weeks after the onset of symptoms. This patient's fall from a horse likely caused splenic rupture, resulting in hemoperitoneum and blood collection in the pouch of Douglas, as seen on this patient's abdominal ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

The kidney may be damaged in blunt abdominal trauma (e.g., this patient's fall), which can manifest with abdominal pain. However, kidney injury is not typically associated with pain that radiates to the left shoulder. Moreover, because the kidney is a retroperitoneal organ, free-fluid collection in the rectovaginal pouch of Douglas would not be expected in the absence of penetrating trauma, because the posterior border of the pouch is the peritoneum. Furthermore, kidney injury is typically associated with hematuria, which is not seen here.
questions.hint: This patient most likely presents with a serious complication of infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 1 hour after being tackled by a bull on his ranch. Immediately after being knocked over, he had pain in his right lower thoracic region. Twenty minutes later, he became dizzy. His wife says he has no history of previous illness and takes no medications. On arrival, he barely responds to painful stimuli. His temperature is 36쨘C (96.8쨘F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 76/62 mm Hg. No source of bleeding is seen besides small lacerations on his extremities. There is a significant ecchymosis in the right lower thoracic region and the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Chest auscultation shows no abnormalities. Peripheral venous access is established, blood samples for crossmatching and blood gas analysis are drawn, and rapid infusion of Ringer lactate (RL) solution is initiated. The patient is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is begun. A FAST scan of the abdomen discloses blood in the hepatorenal recess. After the administration of 1000 mL of RL solution, the patient's blood pressure is 80/64 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate fluid resuscitation with hydroxyethyl starch solution
Transfuse O group, Rh negative packed red blood cells
Perform CT scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage used to be commonly performed in patients with blunt abdominal trauma to identify intraperitoneal hemorrhage. Since the advent of FAST scan, however, this invasive procedure is no longer preferred.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluid resuscitation with hydroxyethyl starch solution is associated with an increased risk of kidney dysfunction and mortality and should generally be avoided in critically ill patients.

C) CORRECT:

Patients in shock with a history of, or ongoing, severe hemorrhage should receive an initial bolus of intravenous saline followed by transfusion of type O Rh negative packed red blood cells (pRBCs). If available, fully crossmatched pRBCs are preferable for this purpose. Early resuscitation with blood reestablishes hemoglobin levels and, therefore, the oxygen-carrying capacity of the intravascular volume. The reestablished capacity prevents organ ischemia and associated metabolic acidosis, both of which can complicate shock. If hemorrhage is extensive and the patient continues to be hemodynamically unstable, plasma and platelets should be transfused in addition to pRBCs at a 1:1:1 ratio. Transfusion of these blood products counters the risk of developing coagulopathy, which is another complication of shock associated with acidosis, hypothermia, trauma itself, fibrinolysis, and dilution due to fluid transfusion. In addition to transfusion of pRBCs, management of this patient should include immediate transfer to the operating room for laparotomy.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen is indicated after blunt trauma in hemodynamically stable patients if an initial FAST scan is inconclusive. This patient, however, is in hemorrhagic shock and hemodynamically unstable. Furthermore, the results of the FAST scan in conjunction with this patient's history of trauma and physical examination findings are conclusive for intraperitoneal bleeding due to liver laceration.

E) INCORRECT:

Norepinephrine infusion to maintain organ perfusion is indicated in patients with hypotension due to septic or cardiogenic shock. This patient, however, has hypovolemic shock. Vasopressors such as norepinephrine should be avoided in this condition because these drugs do not treat the cause of hypovolemia and can lead to organ hypoperfusion and tissue damage (e.g., kidney injury).

F) INCORRECT:

Recombinant activated factor VII (rFVIIa) is approved for the treatment of hemorrhage in patients with hemophilia A and B, acquired hemophilia, factor VII deficiency, or Glanzmann thrombasthenia. rFVIIa is also used off-label in patients with coagulopathy due to trauma. Although this patient has a history of trauma, there are no signs of coagulopathy (e.g., mucosal bleeding, hematoma).
questions.hint: This patient has a history of blunt trauma and presents with tachycardia, hypotension with decreased pulse pressure, tachypnea, and intraperitoneal blood, the combination of which indicates hypovolemic shock as a result of internal hemorrhage. The bleeding most likely comes from liver laceration caused by a rib fracture (as suggested by ecchymosis on the right lower chest). The next step in management should increase blood pressure and ensure oxygen delivery to the tissue.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 4-hour history of nausea and upper abdominal pain. The mother reports that he vomited dark-green secretions 2 hours ago. One day before, he fell off his bicycle and the handlebar struck his abdomen. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. He appears ill. His temperature is 37.0째C (98.6째F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mildly distended abdomen that is tender to palpation. There are multiple ecchymoses on the upper abdomen. Bowel sounds are present. His hemoglobin concentration is 13 mg/dL, serum ALT activity is 38 U/L, and serum amylase activity is 102 U/L. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a large gastric bubble with no free intraperitoneal air. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A splenic laceration can occur in children following blunt abdominal trauma and manifests with acute abdominal pain. However, patients with a splenic laceration usually show signs of blood loss (e.g., low hemoglobin, hemodynamic instability) immediately after injury and the abdominal CT scan would show the splenic injury.
Image Description:

Abdominal CT scan (axial section; IV contrast) of a patient involved in a motor vehicle collision

There is a large splenic laceration (red overlay), identifiable as an irregular hypodensity within the spleen (white overlay).
The splenic capsule has ruptured posteriorly and anterolaterally, resulting in contrast extravasation (hyperdensities marked by a green overlay posteriorly and white arrowhead anterolaterally) and a subcapsular splenic hematoma (isodense fluid marked by a white dashed outline). Contrast extravasation indicates active hemorrhage.

This is the typical radiological appearance of a splenic laceration with a splenic hematoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Intestinal perforation can occur in children following blunt abdominal trauma and manifests with acute abdominal pain and distention, nausea, and vomiting. However, in intestinal perforation, bowel sounds are typically decreased or absent, and patients frequently show signs of peritonitis (e.g., abdominal guarding) or shock. Moreover, intraperitoneal free air would be seen on the abdominal CT scan.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with oral and IV contrast; axial plane) of a patient with abdominal distention

A large amount of free air is seen in the peritoneal cavity (indicated by arrows) anterior to the liver (L) and stomach (St). A perforation site was not identified by CT.

Pneumobilia (example indicated by green overlay) is due to a biliary stent (not shown). Cysts in the right kidney are partially visible on this image (red overlay).

Sp: spleen

C) CORRECT:

In combination with a large gastric bubble on the CT scan, this patient's acute onset of nausea, bilious vomiting, upper abdominal pain, and abdominal distention suggest an upper small bowel obstruction. In a child with a history of recent blunt abdominal trauma (e.g., handlebar injury during a fall from a bicycle), duodenal hematoma is the most likely diagnosis. Duodenal hematoma is a common injury in children following blunt abdominal trauma because the abdominal wall is thinner and less developed, making hollow viscus more prone to injury. The hematoma typically resolves spontaneously in days to weeks. Hemodynamically stable patients can be managed conservatively with nasogastric intubation and total parenteral nutrition. Laparotomy may be indicated in hemodynamically unstable children and/or in those with suspected duodenal perforation.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a duodenal hematoma

A heterogeneous mass with high attenuation areas representing hemorrhage (green overlay) is present in the right upper quadrant in the region of the proximal duodenum.

G = gall bladder, P = pancreas

D) INCORRECT:

Although rare, blunt abdominal trauma in children can cause acute pancreatitis due to pancreatic duct injury. Acute pancreatitis manifests with acute abdominal pain with distention, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal ecchymoses. However, serum amylase levels are elevated in patients with acute pancreatitis and an abdominal CT scan would show features of pancreatic injury (e.g., enlargement of the pancreatic parenchyma with edema) rather than a large gastric bubble.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (without contrast; axial plane)

The pancreas is diffusely enlarged and its margins are indistinct (examples indicated by arrowheads) as a result of inflammation. Inflammatory stranding of intraabdominal fat (examples indicated by arrows) is also seen. The gallbladder is distended and contains sludge and a small calculus (black arrowhead).

E) INCORRECT:

Liver hematoma can occur in children following blunt abdominal trauma and manifest with abdominal pain and distention. However, patients with a liver hematoma typically have elevated liver enzymes and a hepatic hematoma would be seen on an abdominal CT scan.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with IV contrast; axial plane) of a patient involved in a motor vehicle crash

Two biconvex hypodense hematomas (1, green overlay) are seen between the hepatic capsule and parenchyma.

2: spleen; 3: liver; 4: IVC (inferior vena cava)
questions.hint: In most patients with this condition, nonoperative management is sufficient.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining multiple stab wounds and blunt trauma to his chest during a gang fight. On arrival, he has severe chest pain that worsens on inspiration and coughs intermittently. He is alert and in moderate respiratory distress. His temperature is 37.0째C (98.6째F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 85/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. There are multiple entrance wounds and ecchymoses on his chest and upper back. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade is a severe complication of chest trauma and can manifest with sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, and hypotension. However, a chest x-ray would show an enlarged heart silhouette (a water bottle sign in the case of large effusions) with clear lungs rather than mediastinal shift, depressed right hemidiaphragm, and widened right intercostal spaces. In addition to hypotension, cardiac tamponade usually causes muffled heart sounds and distended neck veins (Beck triad).
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lupus pericarditis

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged and demonstrates a globular, or water bottle, configuration due to pericardial effusion (green hatched overlay).

B) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary contusion can develop following blunt chest trauma and manifest with respiratory distress and chest pain. However, chest x-ray typically shows diffuse patchy alveolar infiltrates and white-out or diffuse opacities, not a mediastinal shift, depressed right hemidiaphragm, and widened right intercostal spaces.

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumomediastinum can occur following penetrating chest trauma and manifests with respiratory distress, cough, and chest pain. However, a chest x-ray typically shows a radiolucent outline around the mediastinal structures. Moreover, pneumomediastinum also manifests with subcutaneous emphysema and the Hamman sign.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with left chest trauma

Acute fractures of the posterior left 3rd through 7th ribs are accompanied by tension pneumothorax, with depression of the left hemidiaphragm (indicated by white arrow) and a rightward shift of the mediastinum (indicated by red arrow). The left lung is partially collapsed (green overlay). Pneumomediastinum, or mediastinal emphysema, is visible as vertically oriented linear lucencies in the mediastinum (examples indicated by yellow overlay). Subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and left chest wall is the result of the dissection of mediastinal air into the soft tissues (examples indicated by blue overlay). Air outlining fibers of the pectoralis muscle produces the ginkgo-leaf sign (indicated by red overlay).

Healed fractures of the right 6th, 7th, and 9th ribs are also visible, and an ECG electrode projects over the anterior aspect of the right 2nd rib.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and chest x-ray findings (absence of right bronchovascular markings and mediastinal shift to the contralateral side) after multiple penetrating injuries to the chest indicate a tension pneumothorax. This condition is caused by air trapping in the pleural space, which, if severe enough, can compress the adjacent structures (e.g., contralateral lung, mediastinum) and impair venous return to the heart. This can cause life-threatening cardiopulmonary collapse, which manifests with severe hypotension and tachycardia. Emergency needle thoracostomy, followed by chest tube placement, is the first-line treatment for patients with suspected tension pneumothorax.

Emergency chest tube thoracostomy is indicated in unstable patients, who present with bilateral tension pneumothorax or require mechanical ventilation.
Image Description:

A tension pneumothorax develops secondary to one-way valve mechanism, which is caused by an injury to the lung parenchyma or chest wall and allows air to enter the pleural space during inspiration (valve open) but not escape during expiration (valve closed). Progressive accumulation of air within the pleural space causes an ipsilateral increase in intrapleural pressure, leading to ipsilateral lung collapse and mediastinal shift to the contralateral side. The mediastinal shift compresses the vena cavae, trachea, and the contralateral lung, leading to hemodynamic instability and hypoxia.

E) INCORRECT:

An acquired diaphragmatic hernia can be caused by blunt or penetrating thoracoabdominal trauma and usually manifests with the sudden onset of respiratory distress and chest pain. However, a chest x-ray typically shows hemidiaphragm elevation rather than depression, and a chest translucency or opacity with an air-fluid level (representing the stomach or bowel) would also be expected in a patient with an acquired diaphragmatic hernia.

F) INCORRECT:

A flail chest can result from blunt trauma and would explain this patient's acute onset of dyspnea, tachypnea, and the presence of chest ecchymoses. However, this condition is typically characterized by paradoxical chest movement, which this patient does not have. Moreover, the chest x-ray does not show any rib fractures, which makes the diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view; supine) of patient with a history of trauma

Multiple right rib fractures (red lines) are present, some of which show marked displacement. There is extensive subcutaneous emphysema (examples indicated by arrowheads). The right lung is diffusely opaque (green overlay), likely reflective of pulmonary contusion in view of the trauma history.

White overlay: ribs
questions.hint: Chest x-ray shows a depressed hemidiaphragm and widened intercostal spaces on the right side and a left mediastinal shift.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. On arrival, he is alert and fully oriented and reports right flank pain. Medical history is remarkable for kidney stones and depression. His only medication is sertraline. His temperature is 37째C (98.6째F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 132/75 mm Hg. He appears anxious. Physical examination shows multiple superficial abrasions of the extremities. Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is right flank tenderness and tenderness to deep palpation of the right abdomen without guarding or rebound. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, serum chemistry profile, and coagulation studies, are within normal limits. Urinalysis shows 15 RBC/hpf. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast shows a 1.5-cm laceration of the right kidney with an adjacent, 1.5 x 2-cm hematoma. There is no evidence of urinary extravasation and no free intraperitoneal fluid. Administration of intravenous fluids and analgesics is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A retrograde urethrogram is indicated in all patients with a suspected urethral injury, which commonly develops as a result of trauma and can manifest with hematuria. However, urethral injuries are characterized by presence of blood at the urethral meatus, palpable bladder distension due to an inability to void, and suprapubic pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy should be considered in patients with suspected renal injury following trauma if they are hemodynamically unstable or present with features of active intraabdominal bleeding or injury, such as peritoneal signs. This patient has a small kidney laceration, is hemodynamically stable, and shows no signs of peritoneal irritation. Furthermore, imaging shows no evidence of intraabdominal bleeding.

C) CORRECT:

Conservative management with supportive care and close hemodynamic monitoring is recommended for patients with kidney lacerations who are hemodynamically stable and show no evidence of major renal vascular or urinary collecting system injury. Serial imaging is generally not needed but should be considered if the patient develops signs of deterioration (e.g., worsening flank pain, abdominal distension). Hemodynamically stable patients with vascular or urinary collecting system injuries can also be managed conservatively but should be monitored in the ICU with serial laboratory studies and imaging, as these patients are at increased risk of complications (e.g., bleeding, urinoma). Patients with expanding hematomas but no other signs of active intraabdominal bleeding or injury can be treated with angioembolization. In hemodynamically unstable patients, exploratory laparotomy should be performed.

D) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous nephrostomy may be indicated in a patient with suspected renal pelvic or ureteral injury, both of which can manifest with flank pain and hematuria. However, CT findings of ureteral and renal pelvic injuries include urine extravasation, hydronephrosis, and nonvisualization of the ureter. Moreover, these injuries typically develop in individuals with penetrating or iatrogenic rather than blunt abdominal trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Ureteral stenting may be indicated in patients with suspected ureteral injury, which can develop as a result of abdominal trauma and manifest with flank pain and hematuria. However, CT findings of ureteral injuries include urine extravasation, hydronephrosis, and nonvisualization of the ureter. Moreover, ureteral injuries typically develop in individuals with penetrating or iatrogenic rather than blunt abdominal trauma.
questions.hint: This patient is hemodynamically stable and his CT scan shows a kidney laceration but no major concomitant injury of the renal vascular or urinary collecting system.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after a restrained motor vehicle crash. She reports chest pressure and shortness of breath. She has no medical history and takes no prescription medications. She is lethargic on examination but responds to painful stimuli.
She has a blood pressure of 85/60 mm Hg (equal in both arms), a heart rate of 105 beats per minute that is regular, a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 96% while breathing ambient air.
Her anterior chest is tender to palpation but without notable fractures. She has symmetric chest wall movement on inhalation and expiration and bilateral breath sounds without tracheal deviation. Her heart sounds are muffled, and her jugular veins are notably elevated without lower-extremity edema. Her abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The features of acute cardiac tamponade include hypotension, distended neck veins, and distant, muffled heart sounds. A minority of patients with acute cardiac tamponade present with all three features; their presence together is highly suggestive of the diagnosis. The enlarged cardiac silhouette seen on the chest radiograph is consistent with a pericardial effusion.

Key learning point: The acute findings of hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure in a trauma patient are most indicative of the diagnosis of acute cardiac tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

A flail chest is a life-threatening condition when several ribs are broken in multiple locations, invariably involving pulmonary contusions, which may decrease oxygenation. The characteristic findings include paradoxical motion of the affected ribs (i.e., they move in opposition with the patients respiratory cycle). The chest radiograph shows no evidence of rib fractures.

C) INCORRECT:

An aortic dissection is less likely, given that the patients mediastinum is not enlarged and her upper-extremity blood pressures are equivalent.

D) INCORRECT:

An acute pulmonary contusion manifests with chest pain, hemoptysis, and hypoxemia. It is not typically associated with an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

E) INCORRECT:

The patient has bilateral breath sounds with normal oxygenation and a midline trachea, which would not be expected with a tension pneumothorax. Furthermore, the chest radiograph does not show a pneumothorax or tracheal deviation.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy is brought in by emergency medical services (EMS) after a motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained driver. EMS personnel reports that they had difficulty extricating him from the vehicle, which was older and had no airbags. They also note possible blunt injury to his chest upon impact with the steering wheel.
When you arrive, the patient is awake, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15. He reports chest pain and difficulty breathing. He has a heart rate of 120 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 154/65 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 92% while breathing ambient air. You hear slightly diminished breath sounds on the right and suspect multiple fractured ribs on the same side. The patient appears to have increased work of breathing; on visual examination of the chest, the right side of the rib cage moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration.
A chest radiograph is ordered and pending.
Which one of the following conditions best explains this patients physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Upper-airway obstruction would manifest with stridor and an obstructive breathing pattern. It would not typically cause one side of the chest wall to move in the manner described. The patient also has no reported history of trauma to the neck to cause any swelling or mechanism for upper-airway disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Blunt chest trauma can, on rare occasions, lead to diaphragmatic rupture. In some cases of left-sided rupture, bowel sounds may be audible in the chest. Chest imaging may demonstrate bowel or abdominal viscera in the chest cavity.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a history consistent with blunt trauma to the chest. His chest pain, difficulty breathing, and physical examination consistent with multiple rib fractures should raise suspicion for flail chest.

Normal respiratory mechanics begin with contraction of the diaphragm during inspiration, creating negative intrathoracic pressure. The external intercostal muscles move the rib cage up and out. The chest wall and parietal pleura move out with the rib cage, pulling the visceral pleura and the lung with it. As the volume within the thoracic cavity increases, the pressure within the lung decreases, lowering intrapulmonary pressure relative to atmospheric pressure and allowing air to flow into the lungs.

Flail chest results from fractures of three or more ribs in two or more places, creating a floating segment that loses its mechanical continuity with the remainder of the chest wall. This floating segment causes paradoxical motion of the rib cage, which can be appreciated on physical examination: During inspiration, the broken rib segment paradoxically moves inward and then returns outward during expiration (the opposite of the contralateral normal rib cage), thereby giving the appearance of a flailing chest.

This patients physical examination findings are consistent with broken ribs on the right. In such a clinical scenario, the diaphragm contracts and flattens during inspiration, causing negative intrathoracic pressure; the right side of the chest would then be expected to paradoxically move inward, followed by movement outward during expiration.

Key learning point: The most likely explanation for the rib cage moving inward during inspiration and outward during expiration in a patient with a history of blunt trauma to the chest is flail chest.

D) INCORRECT:

Although a pneumothorax is possible in this patient, breath sounds are audible on the right. Diminished chest-wall movement may be visualized, but the paradoxical motion described in this patient is not consistent with a pneumothorax.

E) INCORRECT:

A hemothorax may cause diminished breath sounds as the pleura is filled with blood. Given this patients apparent rib fractures, a hemothorax is possible, but it would not explain the paradoxical movement of the rib cage noted on physical examination.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) results are negative. An ECG shows absent P waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In the context of a serious motor vehicle collision, this patient's hypotension and tachycardia refractive to fluid resuscitation, including vasopressors, combined with atrial fibrillation on ECG and a negative FAST, are highly suspicious for cardiac contusion. Cardiac contusions may manifest with clinical features ranging from asymptomatic arrhythmias to rapidly fatal cardiac rupture. Blunt chest trauma and/or sudden deceleration can lead to decreased contractility and arrhythmias due to injury to cardiac myocytes and pacemaker cells. Decreased contractility directly contributes to cardiogenic shock with decreased cardiac output and hypotension, as in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Splenic rupture most often occurs in the setting of blunt abdominal trauma and can result in hemodynamic instability secondary to massive intraabdominal blood loss. However, an intraabdominal hemorrhage large enough to lead to deterioration would be seen on the FAST exam.

C) INCORRECT:

A hemothorax might manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, diminished/absent breath sounds, decreased tactile fremitus, dullness on percussion, and flat neck veins. It may also be associated with a raised jugular venous pressure. In severe cases of hemothorax, blood loss into the thoracic cavity can lead to hemorrhagic shock, with subsequent tachycardia and hypotension. However, a hemothorax is distinctly identifiable on chest x-ray or on ultrasound as part of the FAST exam. No signs of internal bleeding are apparent on this patient's FAST exam and the physical exam findings (bibasilar crackles, soft abdomen) make a significant hemothorax even more unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

An aortic dissection may occur as the result of rapid deceleration (e.g., in a motor vehicle accident) and typically manifests with severe tearing chest pain that may radiate to different parts of the body. Aortic dissection is associated with hypotension either if the dissection involves the ascending aorta resulting in cardiac tamponade and/or aortic regurgitation, or if it results in aortic rupture and hemorrhage into the mediastinum. On the FAST exam, however, aortic rupture would be apparent as free fluid above the diaphragm, with secondary cardiac tamponade as fluid accumulates in the pericardium. Moreover, secondary aortic regurgitation severe enough to affect the patient's vitals would be heard on auscultation.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary contusions can occur in the setting of chest trauma and result in chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, and hypoxia as bruising of the lung impairs gas exchange. Symptoms may then worsen following fluid administration as fluid accumulates in the damaged lung. While this patient does have chest pain and tachypnea and deteriorated after receiving fluids, pulmonary contusion would be less likely to cause the arrhythmia or fluid- and vasopressor-resistant hypotension that proved fatal in this patient.
questions.hint: While hypotension following acute trauma should raise concern for blood loss, this patient's negative FAST exam makes intraabdominal or intrathoracic bleeding less likely. Instead, his profound hypotension despite an apparently normal volume status, the bibasilar lung crackles, and elevated jugular venous pressure potentially indicate cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: A 27-year-old soldier is brought to the emergency department of a military hospital 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. He was an unrestrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and chest pain. His temperature is 37.0째C (98.6째F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows bruising on the chest, extremities, and abdomen. The lungs are clear to auscultation and he has normal heart sounds and flat neck veins. The abdomen is flat, soft, and mildly tender. High-flow oxygen and intravenous fluid therapy are initiated. A focused ultrasonographic assessment (FAST scan) shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is indicated for the treatment of cardiac tamponade, which can occur following trauma (due to a hemopericardium) and cause chest pain, dyspnea, and a widened mediastinum. However, patients with cardiac tamponade typically have muffled heart sounds, hemodynamic instability, and distended (rather than flat) neck veins. The normal FAST scan and the absence of an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest x-ray make a hemopericardium unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Blunt force aortic injuries range from small intimal tears and intramural hematomas to aortic rupture. Contrast-enhanced CT angiography (CECT angiography) is indicated for the diagnosis of aortic injury in hemodynamically stable patients and should be performed if the patient has symptoms suggestive of aortic injury (e.g., chest pain), a history of high-energy trauma, or features that suggest aortic injury on the FAST scan (e.g., hemothorax) or chest x-ray (e.g., mediastinal widening, aortic knob loss). CECT angiography has high sensitivity and specificity, can screen for additional vascular injuries (e.g., abdominal aortic injury), and provides anatomical information for planning surgical management. Patients who are hemodynamically unstable should be urgently evaluated with transesophageal echocardiography in the operating room.

C) INCORRECT:

Although aortography, which is performed using vascular catheterization, was previously used to evaluate for aortic pathology, less invasive modalities that are more readily available are now preferred.

D) INCORRECT:

A transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) to identify thoracic aortic injury is indicated in patients who are hemodynamically unstable and cannot be transported safely for other imaging modalities. A hemodynamically stable patient requires a different imaging modality that provides more detailed anatomical information.

E) INCORRECT:

A chest tube can be used to treat patients with a pneumothorax or hemothorax. However, this patient's chest x-ray and FAST scan do not indicate the presence of either of these conditions.
questions.hint: The patient sustained a deceleration injury and has mediastinal widening on chest x-ray, suggesting blunt thoracic aortic injury.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain 35 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 33/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows a 2.5-cm (1-in) laceration on the left side of the chest. There are decreased breath sounds over the left base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9110/mm3, and platelet count is 190,000/mm3. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Diaphragmatic rupture is most commonly caused by penetrating injuries, followed by blunt trauma, both of which can be caused by a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Clinical features include chest/abdominal wall bruises, decreased breath sounds due to herniation of abdominal contents into the chest, and respiratory distress. Chest auscultation may reveal bowel sounds. Chest x-ray may show disturbed contour of the hemidiaphragm, displaced abdominal organs, and mediastinal shift, as well as an hourglass sign if abdominal contents are constricted at the defect. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Diaphragmatic ruptures more commonly occur on the left side because the right diaphragm is protected by the liver. Patients may initially be asymptomatic, so this condition is often not diagnosed immediately.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal perforation may occur in a variety of clinical scenarios, including Boerhaave syndrome, blunt and penetrating chest trauma, and iatrogenic esophageal perforation (e.g., following endoscopy). Patients with esophageal perforation present with chest pain, tachycardia, and tachypnea. However, this condition is often associated with additional findings such as fever and crepitus over the chest due to mediastinal emphysema. Unlike in this patient, a chest x-ray typically shows a widened mediastinum. Herniation of the stomach into the thorax is not typically associated with esophageal perforation.

C) INCORRECT:

Flail chest can cause respiratory distress due to detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall, which results from three or more adjacent ribs fractured in two or more places. While flail chest can occur following high-velocity trauma, the absence of rib fractures on this patient's chest x-ray rules this condition out.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view; supine) of patient with a history of trauma

Multiple right rib fractures (red lines) are present, some of which show marked displacement. There is extensive subcutaneous emphysema (examples indicated by arrowheads). The right lung is diffusely opaque (green overlay), likely reflective of pulmonary contusion in view of the trauma history.

White overlay: ribs

D) INCORRECT:

A pneumothorax can occur spontaneously or following trauma such as a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Patients typically present with tachypnea, dyspnea, chest pain, and unilaterally reduced breath sounds. However, a chest x-ray usually shows a pleural line, a sudden change in radiolucency, and an abrupt stop in pulmonary vascular markings. This patient's x-ray findings are not consistent with a pneumothorax.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A thin white line represents the visceral pleura of the left lung (dotted line). No lung markings are seen peripheral to the visceral pleura (green overlay).

The appearance is consistent with a left pneumothorax. There is no evidence of contralateral mediastinal shift, diaphragmatic depression, or ipsilateral intercostal space widening to suggest tension pneumothorax.

E) INCORRECT:

The phrenic nerve innervates the diaphragm via the nerve roots C3, C4, and C5. Phrenic nerve palsy is often iatrogenic (e.g., following supraclavicular block) and may occasionally occur following trauma. This condition leads to ipsilateral elevation of the diaphragm, which affects pulmonary and cardiac function. Patients can present with dyspnea. However, x-ray usually shows elevation of the diaphragm on the affected side and not herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (lateral view)

There is elevation of the left hemidiaphragm (dashed line) with adjacent atelectasis (yellow overlay) of lung parenchyma and underlying dilated bowel (B).

Blue overlay: hardware left humerus; solid line: right hemidiaphragm
questions.hint: This patient, who has just been in a car accident, is in respiratory distress and has chest pain, decreased breath sounds over his left lung, and a chest x-ray that is typical for this condition.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. On arrival, he is alert and has mild chest pain. His temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. There are coarse breath sounds over the right lung base. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallop. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. He subsequently develops increasing shortness of breath. Arterial blood gas analysis on 60% oxygen shows:


pH
7.36


pCO2
39 mm Hg


pO2
68 mm Hg


HCO3-

18 mEq/L


O2 saturation
81%


An x-ray of the chest shows patchy, irregular infiltrates over the right lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blunt trauma to the thorax (e.g., mild chest pain and mild dyspnea on admission) can result in rib fractures or injury to lobar bronchi, and thereby cause a pneumothorax, which also manifests with dyspnea and hypoxemia. However, the classic findings in pneumothorax (e.g., decreased breath sounds, hyperresonance on the affected side, increased radiolucency on chest x-ray) are missing.

B) INCORRECT:

Tracheobronchial injury (TBI) has many causes, including trauma to the chest or neck, deceleration injury, and/or inhalation of hot smoke and noxious gases (usually in association with burns). In the case of TBI due to blunt trauma, injury usually occurs within 2 cm of the carina or at the origin of lobar bronchi. In such a scenario, TBI would manifest with acute dyspnea, as well as clinical features of subcutaneous emphysema (e.g., palpable crepitus), pneumomediastinum (e.g., Hamman crunch), and/or pneumothorax (e.g., decreased breath sounds, hyperresonant percussion note). The absence of characteristic clinical and radiological findings, as well as the delayed onset of dyspnea in this patient, makes the diagnosis of TBI unlikely.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.

Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

C) CORRECT:

Pulmonary contusion is the most common lung injury following blunt injury to the chest wall (e.g., during a motor vehicle accident). Damage to the capillaries in the lung parenchyma results in pulmonary edema and/or bleeding within contused lung tissue, which appears as a patchy infiltrate on chest x-ray. Excessive fluid administration worsens pulmonary edema, as the damaged capillaries leak fluid into the lungs.

D) INCORRECT:

A massive hemothorax can manifest with acute dyspnea, hypoxemia, tachycardia, and hypotension. However, a hemothorax appears on a chest x-ray as a singular and continuous collection of fluid in the dependent portion of the thorax, not as patchy infiltrates.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute respiratory distress (ARDS) also manifests with acute dyspnea, hypoxemia, and alveolar or interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray. However, ARDS arises within the context of a severe inflammatory reaction that typically develops over the course of 1236 hours after the initial insult. The appearance of dyspnea and hypoxia within an hour of the event, as well as the localization of the infiltrate in the right lung base (ARDS affects the entire lung parenchyma), makes ARDS highly unlikely. ARDS can occur as a complication of this patient's condition.
questions.hint: This patient developed dyspnea and hypoxia that worsens after giving fluids, indicating damage to the pulmonary vasculature.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and is in severe pain. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. Examination shows superficial abrasions and diffuse crepitus at the left shoulder level. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The upper part of the left chest wall moves inward during inspiration. Breath sounds are absent on the left. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diaphragmatic rupture can occur after high-energy trauma and, in case of herniation of abdominal organs into the chest, cause respiratory distress with decreased breath sounds in the affected hemithorax. However, in such a scenario, bowel sounds would be heard during auscultation of the affected hemithorax. In addition, diaphragmatic rupture would not explain the paradoxical motion of a segment of the left chest wall.

B) INCORRECT:

Phrenic nerve damage may be caused by trauma, malignancy, or surgery and result in partial or complete paralysis of the diaphragm. Phrenic nerve paralysis may be asymptomatic or manifest with dyspnea. Unilateral phrenic nerve paralysis leads to the paradoxical upward movement of the affected hemidiaphragm. The condition would not explain the paradoxical motion of a segment of the left chest wall.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade typically presents with hypotension, tachycardia, jugular venous distention, and pulsus paradoxus. Although this patient is hypotensive and tachycardic, no other signs of cardiac tamponade are present. In addition, cardiac tamponade would not explain the paradoxical motion of the chest wall.

D) INCORRECT:

Sternal fracture classically occurs after blunt anterior chest trauma such as that caused by a motor vehicle collision. It is often associated with myocardial contusions. Although this patient may have an associated sternal fracture, this type of injury does not sufficiently explain his respiratory distress and the paradoxical movement of the chest wall.

E) CORRECT:

A flail chest is the detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall as a result of 3 adjacent rib fractures in 2 places. This floating rib cage segment is decoupled from the chest wall and causes paradoxical chest movement. Upon inspiration, as the intrathoracic pressure drops, the unstable segment will be pulled inwards by the negative pressure, and during expiration, the floating segment moves outward. This condition usually results from high-energy blunt trauma to the chest (e.g., motor vehicle collision). Patients with flail chest commonly present with features of respiratory distress (e.g., dyspnea, tachypnea), which can be due to hypoventilation (as a result of pain), pulmonary contusions, pneumothorax, and/or hemothorax.
Image Description:

Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.
questions.hint: Mechanical ventilation with positive end-expiratory pressure helps counter the paradoxical breathing described here.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling 7 feet onto a flat-top wooden post. On arrival, he is in severe pain and breathing rapidly. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. There is an impact wound in the left fourth intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Auscultation shows tracheal deviation to the right and absent breath sounds over the left lung. There is dullness to percussion over the left chest. Neck veins are flat. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray is shown. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade may manifest with tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. However, neck veins would be distended instead of collapsed, and heart sounds would be muffled on auscultation. Also, tracheal deviation would not be present in an isolated case of cardiac tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchial rupture would manifest with subcutaneous emphysema and hemoptysis. Clinical features of a pneumothorax such as hyperresonant lung fields would also be present in distal tracheobronchial tree injuries. The absence of any of these findings suggests a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.

Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

C) INCORRECT:

Tension pneumothorax may manifest with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, decreased breath sounds on the affected side, and deviation of the trachea to the opposite side. However, neck veins would be distended instead of collapsed because the mediastinal shift that occurs with a tension pneumothorax compresses the superior vena cava. Also, lung fields on the affected side would be hyperresonant instead of dull on percussion.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

Much of the left hemithorax is hyperlucent, with a lack of vascular markings when compared to the right hemithorax. Lobulated opacities that project through the cardiac silhouette and along the left heart border represent collapsed lobes of the left lung (green overlay).

Accompanying depression of the left hemidiaphragm (arrowheads), mass effect on the mediastinum, and widening of some intercostal spaces (double-headed arrows) are signs of tension pneumothorax, which requires immediate intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

A flail chest could manifest with respiratory distress and tachypnea. A patient with flail chest classically exhibits paradoxical movement of a part of the chest wall on respiration. Although this sign may be absent due to respiratory splinting, a mediastinal shift (tracheal deviation), decreased breath sounds, and a dull note on percussion are not characteristic signs of a flail chest. The absence of bony crepitus also suggests that the patient does not have a rib fracture. A different diagnosis must be considered.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view; supine) of patient with a history of trauma

Multiple right rib fractures (red lines) are present, some of which show marked displacement. There is extensive subcutaneous emphysema (examples indicated by arrowheads). The right lung is diffusely opaque (green overlay), likely reflective of pulmonary contusion in view of the trauma history.

White overlay: ribs

E) CORRECT:

Hemothorax can develop following blunt chest trauma. This patient exhibits all the signs and symptoms of a massive hemothorax, i.e., tachycardia, hypotension, tachypnea, flat neck veins, decreased breath sounds, and dullness on percussion on the affected side, as well as tracheal deviation to the opposite side. A hemothorax must be drained in most cases because blood in the pleural cavity may clot if not evacuated, resulting in a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection). Treatment usually consists of chest tube insertion into the 4th5th intercostal space at the midaxillary line in order to allow the blood to drain away and improve lung ventilation. Conservative management may be considered to treat small hemothoraces in consultation with a specialist but has a significant failure rate.
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray shows left-sided opacity and blunting of the costophrenic angle.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after falling and hitting his left flank on a concrete block. On arrival, he has severe left-sided chest pain. His temperature is 37.5째C (99.5째F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 17/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows multiple abrasions on his left flank and trunk. The left lateral chest wall is tender to palpation and bony crepitus is present. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative. An x-ray of the chest shows nondisplaced fractures of the left 4th and 5th ribs and clear lung fields bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admission and surveillance in the intensive care unit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Continuous positive airway pressure is indicated for refractory atelectasis following rib fractures. It is not needed as an initial preventive measure for rib fractures without refractory atelectasis, especially since it can cause patient discomfort, gastric distention, hypoventilation, and barotrauma.

B) INCORRECT:

Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary in the treatment of severe or complicated rib fracture cases, especially in cases involving flail chest. But flail chest is a complication involving three or more rib fractures. In addition, this patient does not show the paradoxical chest movement typical of flail chest, nor does he have evidence of respiratory distress (e.g., hypoxemia). Although he has shallow breathing, it is most likely due to the pain he is experiencing.

C) INCORRECT:

Admission and surveillance in the intensive care unit may be warranted in older patients with 6 rib fractures, or in those with evidence of complications such as pneumothorax or hemothorax. This patient's chest x-ray shows only two fractured ribs and clear lung fields bilaterally, ruling out pneumothorax or hemothorax.

D) CORRECT:

Conservative fracture management is recommended for patients who have < 3 rib fractures and no evidence of fracture displacement, complications of rib fractures, or other traumatic fractures. In patients with a rib fracture, the pain accompanying chest wall expansion can cause reflex hypoventilation and cough reflex suppression. Adequate pain control is important in preventing hypoventilation and its sequelae (e.g., atelectasis). NSAIDs are most commonly used in these patients, and can also be combined with opioids or intercostal nerve blocks if necessary.

Hospital admission is generally warranted in patients with 3 rib fractures, displaced rib fractures, signs of flail chest, or other complications of rib fractures (e.g., severe pulmonary contusions, renal laceration, splenic laceration). Rib fractures that cause pneumothorax or hemothorax may warrant tube thoracostomy. For falls in older individuals, a workup to identify risk factors for falls would be required.

E) INCORRECT:

Open reduction and internal fixation may be considered for treatment of some rib fractures, particularly those that cause flail chest or chest wall deformities. But flail chest is a complication involving three or more rib fractures. In addition, this patient does not show the paradoxical chest movement typical of flail chest, nor does he have evidence of respiratory distress (e.g., hypoxemia). Although he has shallow breathing, it is most likely due to the pain he is experiencing.
questions.hint: This patient has traumatic fracture of two ribs and requires treatment to prevent atelectasis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a bar fight. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the left side of the back. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 12th rib on the left side. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following injuries?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The liver lies in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen deep to the 5th12th ribs. Right-sided rib fractures are commonly associated with liver injury due to direct transmission of force from the causative blow to the liver and/or penetration of the liver by a fractured segment of a rib. This patient has sustained a left-sided 12th rib fracture, making a liver injury unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

A pneumothorax can develop if there is an inlet of air into the pleural cavity. The posterior attachment of the parietal pleura extends to the 12th rib. The inferior border of the lungs extends only to the 10th rib posteriorly but could be injured and result in a pneumothorax if a fractured segment of the 12th rib penetrates the lung parenchyma during deep inspiration. However, another organ that lies in close proximity to the 12th rib is more likely to be injured.

C) INCORRECT:

The colon is a hollow organ that is elastic and compressible. It is rarely injured in blunt force injuries. Although the splenic flexure of the colon lies in the vicinity of the left 12th rib, they are not in direct contact with one another. Colon perforation due to a fractured segment of a rib is unlikely in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The kidneys normally lie in a paraspinal, retroperitoneal position that extends from T12L3. The right kidney is displaced more inferiorly because of the liver. Inferior rib fractures (1012th ribs) are commonly associated with solid organ injuries to the liver, spleen, and/or kidneys. This patient has sustained a fracture of the posterior aspect of the left 12th rib as is evident from the tenderness over his back and the x-ray findings, which makes a kidney laceration the most likely associated injury.

Left lower rib fractures also commonly cause splenic injury (including splenic rupture) due to the proximity of the posterior surface of the spleen to the left 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs. Splenic injury is more common than kidney injury.
Image Description:

The superior pole of the left kidney is located approximately at T12, while the right kidney is located approximately 3 cm lower due to expansion of the liver.

E) INCORRECT:

The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ that extends diagonally from the C-loop of the duodenum, anterior to the L2 vertebra (pancreatic head) to the splenic hilum, anterior to the T12 vertebra (pancreatic tail). The pancreas is well-protected from blunt abdominal trauma because it is surrounded by the liver, spleen, stomach, small intestine, left kidney, and the left lower ribs, which diffuse the transmission of force from the causative blow. A forceful blow to the epigastrium (e.g., from falling on the handlebar of a bike) is more likely to injure the body of the pancreas rather than a posterior blow, which this patient has sustained.
Image Description:

The main pancreatic duct and the common bile duct merge and enter the descending part of the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla. The accessory duct enters at the minor duodenal papilla.

Note: individual ductal anatomy may vary
questions.hint: The lower ribs, also known as floating ribs, are not attached to the sternum. Fractured ribs can damage visceral organs.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was a restrained passenger. On arrival, she is incoherent and in respiratory distress. Her pulse is 130/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 88/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%. Examination shows dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows depression of the left main bronchus, left pleural effusion, tracheal deviation to the right, and a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary contusion typically occurs after blunt trauma and can manifest with tachycardia, respiratory distress, and hypoxia. However, it does not commonly present with dullness on percussion. Additionally, the chest x-ray typically shows patchy alveolar infiltrates and not a widened mediastinum, as described above.

B) INCORRECT:

Traumatic bronchial rupture often results from high-velocity blunt chest wall trauma and can manifest with respiratory distress. However, it is typically associated with pneumothorax and subcutaneous emphysema, which are not seen here.

C) CORRECT:

A widened mediastinum, tracheal deviation to the right, depression of the left main bronchus, and hemothorax (suggested by left pleural effusion) are consistent with thoracic aortic rupture (TAR). TAR can be traumatic (e.g., due to high-velocity blunt chest wall trauma) or spontaneous (e.g., following aortic dissection). Only around 20% of patients with blunt traumatic aortic injuries survive long enough to reach the hospital, therefore, immediate resuscitation and prompt surgical repair of the thoracic aorta is required in patients with suggestive findings (e.g., symptoms of respiratory distress, features of hemorrhagic shock).

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade results from conditions such as pericarditis, chest trauma, malignancies, or kidney dysfunction. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with respiratory distress. This patient has hypotension, but she does not have the jugular venous distention or muffled heart sounds that would be expected in an individual with cardiac tamponade (Becks triad). Additionally, in contrast to this vignette, x-ray findings of cardiac tamponade would typically include an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

E) INCORRECT:

While a tension pneumothorax can manfiest with tachycardia and hypoxia, the lung is typically hyperresonant and not dull to percussion. Additionally, although mediastinal shift is seen on the chest x-ray of tension pneumothorax, absent lung markings would also be expected and there would not be a widened mediastinum.
questions.hint: This condition should always be considered in patients presenting with respiratory distress and signs of developing shock after trauma from rapid deceleration (e.g., high-speed motor vehicle collision). The x-ray findings are highly suggestive of the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after losing control of his bicycle and colliding with a parked car. He was thrown over the handlebars and hit the ground. He has mild pain in his legs and on his right side but says that he feels well otherwise. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is tenderness to palpation over the right thorax. There is no pelvic instability. A voided urine specimen is clear. Microscopic examination of the urine shows 85 RBCs/hpf. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no free intraabdominal fluid. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 11th rib on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous pyelography (IVP) is used for the evaluation of possible renal disease, detection of renal stones, or to assess potential contrast extravasation if contrast-enhanced CT images are not diagnostic. IVP was formerly a preferred imaging modality for renal trauma; however, a different test has supplanted IVP as the imaging modality of choice.

B) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy after BAT is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients with signs of peritonitis and hemodynamically stable patients with evidence of free intraabdominal fluid on imaging. This patient is hemodynamically stable and focused assessment with sonography for trauma is normal.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with BAT, a CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating abdominal injuries, including those of the genitourinary tract. BAT is a major cause of mortality and requires a high degree of clinical suspicion, even if a patient's initial presentation does not suggest any significant intraabdominal injury. This patient with suspected renal trauma requires a CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis to establish the diagnosis and further assess the degree of trauma.

D) INCORRECT:

Retrograde urethrocystography is used to evaluate the lower genitourinary tract and urinary bladder. It is indicated in patients with gross hematuria or blood at the urethral meatus following a pelvic fracture. This patient, however, only has microscopic hematuria and no signs of a pelvic fracture. Therefore, a retrograde urethrocystography is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Observation and follow-up may be appropriate in patients who are hemodynamically stable and have no signs of traumatic injury. Although mild microscopic hematuria is common following BAT and does not necessarily indicate genitourinary injury, this patient has evidence of a right rib fracture, which is concerning for a renal injury. Therefore, observation and follow-up would not be an appropriate next step.
questions.hint: The combination of a fracture of the 11th rib on the right side and microscopic hematuria in a patient with a history of blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) should raise concern for renal injury.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He has bruising across the anterior chest wall and is tachypneic. During inspiration, a segment of his left chest wall moves inward while the rest expands outward. He is increasingly agitated and using accessory muscles to breathe (see lab results).


Respiratory rate
36/min


Oxygen saturation

87% on a nonrebreather mask




Test
Result
Normal Values



Arterial blood gas




 pH
7.30
7.36 - 7.45


 PCO2

8.0 kPa
4.7 - 6.0 kPa


 PO2

7.5 kPa
10.6 - 14.2 kPa



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Parenteral analgesics are important for pain management in chest trauma but are insufficient alone in this case. The patient shows signs of flail chest and respiratory failure, with paradoxical chest wall movement, hypoxemia, and hypercapnia. Pain management does not address the ventilatory insufficiency or disrupted chest wall dynamics. Positive pressure ventilation is necessary to ensure proper oxygenation and CO2 elimination, alongside analgesia.

B) CORRECT:

Flail chest manifests with paradoxical chest wall movement due to multiple rib fractures, leading to impaired ventilation and oxygenation. This patient exhibits signs of respiratory failure, including tachypnea, accessory muscle use, hypoxemia, and acidosis (pH 7.30, PCO2 8.0 kPa, PO2 7.5 kPa). Endotracheal intubation with mechanical ventilation is essential to secure the airway, stabilize the chest wall, and optimize gas exchange. Mechanical ventilation reduces the work of breathing and prevents further respiratory compromise, addressing both ventilatory failure and potential hemodynamic instability from severe chest trauma.

Key learning point: In cases of flail chest with respiratory distress and hypoxemia, the priority is to ensure adequate ventilation and oxygenation, often requiring assisted ventilation.

C) INCORRECT:

High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) oxygen therapy can improve oxygenation in moderate hypoxemic respiratory failure but is inadequate for this patient. The flail chest, indicated by paradoxical chest wall movement and severe respiratory compromise, requires more than oxygenation support. The arterial blood gases show hypoxemia and hypercapnia, indicating inadequate ventilation. HFNC does not provide sufficient ventilatory support or stabilize the chest wall, making it unsuitable for this scenario.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical fixation of rib fractures is considered for persistent chest wall instability or non-union issues later in the clinical course. This patient requires immediate stabilization of the airway and ventilation support due to respiratory insufficiency, as indicated by paradoxical chest wall movement, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and hypercapnia. Endotracheal intubation and positive pressure ventilation are prioritized to restore effective chest wall mechanics and improve gas exchange.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after sustaining multiple blunt traumas in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He complains of diffuse abdominal discomfort but denies other injuries. Examination reveals a seatbelt sign across the lower abdomen and mild diffuse tenderness without guarding or rebound. Laboratory evaluations show hemoglobin 130 g/L (reference range 130170 g/L) and lactate 2 mmol/L (normal <2 mmol/L). Focused ultrasound of the abdomen shows no free fluid (see report).


Heart rate
88/min


Blood pressure
125/80 mmHg


Respiratory rate
16/min


Temperature
37.2째C


Focused ultrasound of the abdomen: No free fluid
Which diagnostic test is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for internal abdominal injuries?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serial FAST exams can be useful in unstable patients or when initial findings are ambiguous. However, this patient's mechanism of injury and physical findings suggest potential injuries that may not immediately result in detectable free fluid. Ultrasound is less sensitive for low-grade injuries or those not producing significant fluid early. Waiting for a repeat ultrasound may delay diagnosis and management in a patient with significant trauma risk factors.

B) CORRECT:

In hemodynamically stable patients with blunt abdominal trauma, contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) is the preferred diagnostic tool.
